kural.pope_couplet: A, as its first of letters, every speech maintains;The "Primal Deity" is first through all the world's domains
kural.pope_exp: As the letter A is the first of all letters, so the eternal God is first in the world
kural.kannan_exp: A is the first of the alphabet; God is the primary force of the world.

kural.pope_couplet: No fruit have men of all their studied lore,Save they the 'Purely Wise One's' feet adore
kural.pope_exp: What Profit have those derived from learning, who worship not the good feet of Him who is possessed of pure knowledge ?
kural.kannan_exp: What is the use of all your learning, if you can’t surrender yourself at the feet of God.

kural.pope_couplet: His feet, 'Who o'er the full-blown flower hath past,' who gainIn bliss long time shall dwell above this earthly plain
kural.pope_exp: They who are united to the glorious feet of Him who passes swiftly over the flower of the mind, shall flourish long above all worlds
kural.kannan_exp: Those who surrender themselves at feet of the one, who resides in the flower-like hearts of all, will live long and well.

kural.pope_couplet: His foot, 'Whom want affects not, irks not grief,' who gainShall not, through every time, of any woes complain
kural.pope_exp: To those who meditate the feet of Him who is void of desire or aversion, evil shall never come
kural.kannan_exp: Those who surrender at the feet of the one, who doesn’t have wants or hates, will never have any hassles anywhere.

kural.pope_couplet: The men, who on the 'King's' true praised delight to dwell,Affects not them the fruit of deeds done ill or well
kural.pope_exp: The two-fold deeds that spring from darkness shall not adhere to those who delight in the true praise of God
kural.kannan_exp: Fate, which impacts those in the darkness of ignorance, will not impede those who hail the true glory of God.

kural.pope_couplet: Long live they blest, who 've stood in path from falsehood freed;His, 'Who quenched lusts that from the sense-gates five proceed'
kural.pope_exp: Those shall long proposer who abide in the faultless way of Him who has destroyed the five desires of the senses
kural.kannan_exp: Those who follow the true moral path of the one, who has doused the desires of the five senses, will last long.

kural.pope_couplet: Unless His foot, 'to Whom none can compare,' men gain,'Tis hard for mind to find relief from anxious pain
kural.pope_exp: Anxiety of mind cannot be removed, except from those who are united to the feet of Him who is incomparable
kural.kannan_exp: Except for those who surrender at the feet of the one, for whom, there is no simile, it is tough to cure the mental rues.

kural.pope_couplet: Unless His feet 'the Sea of Good, the Fair and Bountiful,' men gain,'Tis hard the further bank of being's changeful sea to attain
kural.pope_exp: None can swim the sea of vice, but those who are united to the feet of that gracious Being who is a sea of virtue
kural.kannan_exp: Except those who surrender at the feet of God, the ocean of morality, others will struggle to cross the ocean of desire.

kural.pope_couplet: Before His foot, 'the Eight-fold Excellence,' with unbent head,Who stands, like palsied sense, is to all living functions dead
kural.pope_exp: The head that worships not the feet of Him who is possessed of eight attributes, is as useless as a sense without the power of sensation
kural.kannan_exp: The head that doesn’t bow to God, is similar to the organs that don’t have the right senses.

kural.pope_couplet: They swim the sea of births, the 'Monarch's' foot who gain;None others reach the shore of being's mighty main
kural.pope_exp: None can swim the great sea of births but those who are united to the feet of God
kural.kannan_exp: Those who surrender at the feet of God, will cross the great ocean of life; others won’t.

kural.pope_couplet: The world its course maintains through life that rain unfailing gives;Thus rain is known the true ambrosial food of all that lives
kural.pope_exp: By the continuance of rain the world is preserved in existence; it is therefore worthy to be called ambrosia
kural.kannan_exp: The world survives because of the rains and therefore rain is known to be the nectar of immortality.

kural.pope_couplet: The rain makes pleasant food for eaters rise;As food itself, thirst-quenching draught supplies
kural.pope_exp: Rain produces good food, and is itself food
kural.kannan_exp: Oh rain! You not only create everything we eat, you are the indispensable food yourself.

kural.pope_couplet: If clouds, that promised rain, deceive, and in the sky remain,Famine, sore torment, stalks o'er earth's vast ocean-girdled plain
kural.pope_exp: If the cloud, withholding rain, deceive (our hopes) hunger will long distress the sea-girt spacious world
kural.kannan_exp: If the skies fail to rain, the world, though surrounded by sea, will yet suffer of hunger.

kural.pope_couplet: If clouds their wealth of waters fail on earth to pour,The ploughers plough with oxen's sturdy team no more
kural.pope_exp: If the abundance of wealth imparting rain diminish, the labour of the plough must cease
kural.kannan_exp: If the monsoons fail, farmers won’t till their lands to produce food.

kural.pope_couplet: 'Tis rain works all: it ruin spreads, then timely aid supplies;As, in the happy days before, it bids the ruined rise
kural.pope_exp: Rain by its absence ruins men; and by its existence restores them to fortune
kural.kannan_exp: It is the tormentor; it is the saviour of the tormented: the rain is everything for us.

kural.pope_couplet: If from the clouds no drops of rain are shed'Tis rare to see green herb lift up its head
kural.pope_exp: If no drop falls from the clouds, not even the green blade of grass will be seen
kural.kannan_exp: Unless drops of precious rain fall down, not even grass will sprout its head.

kural.pope_couplet: If clouds restrain their gifts and grant no rain,The treasures fail in ocean's wide domain
kural.pope_exp: Even the wealth of the wide sea will be diminished, if the cloud that has drawn (its waters) up gives them not back again (in rain)
kural.kannan_exp: Even the vast ocean will start shrinking, if the clouds that took the water away from it, don’t pour it back.

kural.pope_couplet: If heaven grow dry, with feast and offering never more,Will men on earth the heavenly ones adore
kural.pope_exp: If the heaven dry up, neither yearly festivals, nor daily worship will be offered in this world, to the celestials
kural.kannan_exp: Special offerings and daily rituals to gods will stop, if the skies dry up.

kural.pope_couplet: If heaven its watery treasures ceases to dispense,Through the wide world cease gifts, and deeds of 'penitence'
kural.pope_exp: If rain fall not, penance and alms-deeds will not dwell within this spacious world
kural.kannan_exp: Charity and penance will both cease to exist in this world, if the clouds are not charitable.

kural.pope_couplet: When water fails, functions of nature cease, you say;Thus when rain fails, no men can walk in 'duty's ordered way'
kural.pope_exp: If it be said that the duties of life cannot be discharged by any person without water, so without rain there cannot be the flowing of water
kural.kannan_exp: World can’t survive without water and morality can’t exist without rains.

kural.pope_couplet: The settled rule of every code requires, as highest good,Their greatness who, renouncing all, true to their rule have stood
kural.pope_exp: The end and aim of all treatise is to extol beyond all other excellence, the greatness of those who, while abiding in the rule of conduct peculiar to their state, have abandoned all desire
kural.kannan_exp: All books willingly conclude as the most excellent, the greatness of those with the right conduct who have given up attachment.

kural.pope_couplet: As counting those that from the earth have passed away,'Tis vain attempt the might of holy men to say
kural.pope_exp: To describe the measure of the greatness of those who have forsaken the two-fold desires, is like counting the dead
kural.kannan_exp: Trying to quantify the greatness of those who have overcome desire is like counting those who have died till now.

kural.pope_couplet: Their greatness earth transcends, who, way of both worlds weighed,In this world take their stand, in virtue's robe arrayed
kural.pope_exp: The greatness of those who have discovered the properties of both states of being, and renounced the world, shines forth on earth (beyond all others)
kural.kannan_exp: The greatness of those who have known the nature of both worlds, And have eschewed desire to live a righteous life, is most admirable in this world.

kural.pope_couplet: He, who with firmness, curb the five restrains,Is seed for soil of yonder happy plains
kural.pope_exp: He who guides his five senses by the hook of wisdom will be a seed in the world of heaven
kural.kannan_exp: Using the ankus called resoluteness, one who controls the elephant named five senses, is sowing for future glory.

kural.pope_couplet: Their might who have destroyed 'the five', shall soothly tellIndra, the lord of those in heaven's wide realms that dwell
kural.pope_exp: Indra, the king of the inhabitants of the spacious heaven, is himself, a sufficient proof of the strength of him who has subdued his five senses
kural.kannan_exp: God, the king of heavens, is an example of what the ability to conquer one’s five senses can result in.

kural.pope_couplet: Things hard in the doing will great men do;Things hard in the doing the mean eschew
kural.pope_exp: The great will do those things which is difficult to be done; but the mean cannot do them
kural.kannan_exp: What separates the great from the ordinary is their ability to do the seemingly impossible.

kural.pope_couplet: Taste, light, touch, sound, and smell: who knows the wayOf all the five,- the world submissive owns his sway
kural.pope_exp: The world is within the knowledge of him who knows the properties of taste, sight, touch, hearing and smell
kural.kannan_exp: One who has analysed and conquered the urges of taste, sight, touch, sound and smell, will control this world.

kural.pope_couplet: The might of men whose word is never vain,The 'secret word' shall to the earth proclaim
kural.pope_exp: The hidden words of the men whose words are full of effect, will shew their greatness to the world
kural.kannan_exp: The words of those glorious people, who control their minds completely, become the gospel.

kural.pope_couplet: The wrath 'tis hard e'en for an instant to endure,Of those who virtue's hill have scaled, and stand secure
kural.pope_exp: The anger of those who have ascended the mountain of goodness, though it continue but for a moment, cannot be resisted
kural.kannan_exp: Those who have scaled the mountain of morality will not allow their anger to last for a moment.

kural.pope_couplet: Towards all that breathe, with seemly graciousness adorned they live;And thus to virtue's sons the name of 'Anthanar' men give
kural.pope_exp: The virtuous are truly called Anthanar; because in their conduct towards all creatures they are clothed in kindness
kural.kannan_exp: All (and only) those righteous people, who shower love on all living beings, can be classified as Anthanar*.

kural.pope_couplet: It yields distinction, yields prosperity; what gainGreater than virtue can a living man obtain
kural.pope_exp: Virtue will confer heaven and wealth; what greater source of happiness can man possess ?
kural.kannan_exp: Righteousness yields good reputation and wealth; is there anything more precious?

kural.pope_couplet: No greater gain than virtue aught can cause;No greater loss than life oblivious of her laws
kural.pope_exp: There can be no greater source of good than (the practice of) virtue; there can be no greater source of evil than the forgetfulness of it
kural.kannan_exp: Rectitude is the most precious possession; there is nothing more pernicious than straying from it.

kural.pope_couplet: To finish virtue's work with ceaseless effort strive,What way thou may'st, where'er thou see'st the work may thrive
kural.pope_exp: As much as possible, in every way, incessantly practise virtue
kural.kannan_exp: Keep doing the morally right things, in every possible manner, wherever you go.

kural.pope_couplet: Spotless be thou in mind! This only merits virtue's name;All else, mere pomp of idle sound, no real worth can claim
kural.pope_exp: Let him who does virtuous deeds be of spotless mind; to that extent is virtue; all else is vain show
kural.kannan_exp: True moral integrity lies in being flawless in your thoughts; everything else is loud and blatant posturing.

kural.pope_couplet: 'Tis virtue when, his footsteps sliding not through envy, wrath,Lust, evil speech-these four, man onwards moves in ordered path
kural.pope_exp: That conduct is virtue which is free from these four things, viz, malice, desire, anger and bitter speech
kural.kannan_exp: Righteousness is all about removing the four flaws – envy, desire, anger and harmful words.

kural.pope_couplet: Do deeds of virtue now Say not, 'To-morrow we'll be wise';Thus, when thou diest, shalt thou find a help that never dies
kural.pope_exp: Defer not virtue to another day; receive her now; and at the dying hour she will be your undying friend
kural.kannan_exp: Do the righteous deeds now without waiting for senility to set in; they will remain your permanent companions then.

kural.pope_couplet: Needs not in words to dwell on virtue's fruits: compareThe man in litter borne with them that toiling bear
kural.pope_exp: The fruit of virtue need not be described in books; it may be inferred from seeing the bearer of a palanquin and the rider therein
kural.kannan_exp: One man lifting another on a palanquin, can’t be justified as the fruit of any prior moral deeds.

kural.pope_couplet: If no day passing idly, good to do each day you toil,A stone it will be to block the way of future days of moil
kural.pope_exp: If one allows no day to pass without some good being done, his conduct will be a stone to block up the passage to other births
kural.kannan_exp: Never let a day pass without a good deed; it makes this life fulfilling and the next unnecessary.

kural.pope_couplet: What from virtue floweth, yieldeth dear delight;All else extern, is void of glory's light
kural.pope_exp: Only that pleasure which flows from domestic virtue is pleasure; all else is not pleasure, and it is without praise
kural.kannan_exp: True joy blossoms only due to righteous deeds; all else cause unhappiness and disrepute.

kural.pope_couplet: 'Virtue' sums the things that should be done;'Vice' sums the things that man should shun
kural.pope_exp: That is virtue which each ought to do, and that is vice which each should shun
kural.kannan_exp: A righteous deed deserves to be done; an evil deed ought to be avoided to protect oneself from infamy.

kural.pope_couplet: The men of household virtue, firm in way of good, sustainThe other orders three that rule professed maintain
kural.pope_exp: He will be called a (true) householder, who is a firm support to the virtuous of the three orders in
kural.kannan_exp: A good family person is one who supports all three relationships (parents, wife, children) in a balanced and righteous manner.

kural.pope_couplet: To anchorites, to indigent, to those who've passed away,The man for household virtue famed is needful held and stay
kural.pope_exp: He will be said to flourish in domestic virtue who aids the forsaken, the poor, and the dead
kural.kannan_exp: A good family person also extends support to saints, poor and needy.

kural.pope_couplet: The manes, God, guests kindred, self, in due degree,These five to cherish well is chiefest charity
kural.pope_exp: The chief (duty of the householder) is to preserve the five-fold rule (of conduct) towards the manes, the Gods, his guests, his relations and himself
kural.kannan_exp: Teachers, God, guests, relatives and oneself – it is important to nurture all these five in addition to the family.

kural.pope_couplet: Who shares his meal with other, while all guilt he shuns,His virtuous line unbroken though the ages runs
kural.pope_exp: His descendants shall never fail who, living in the domestic state, fears vice (in the acquisition of property) and shares his food (with others)
kural.kannan_exp: One who earns well but avoids the blame of hoarding wealth, by philanthropy, will lead a complete life with no complaints.

kural.pope_couplet: If love and virtue in the household reign,This is of life the perfect grace and gain
kural.pope_exp: If the married life possess love and virtue, these will be both its duty and reward
kural.kannan_exp: If love and virtue pervade the family life, they become the characteristic and fruit of the family life.

kural.pope_couplet: If man in active household life a virtuous soul retain,What fruit from other modes of virtue can he gain
kural.pope_exp: What will he who lives virtuously in the domestic state gain by going into the other, (ascetic) state ?
kural.kannan_exp: The only way to live is to live righteously; if you set aside virtues, what more is there to gain?

kural.pope_couplet: In nature's way who spends his calm domestic days,'Mid all that strive for virtue's crown hath foremost place
kural.pope_exp: Among all those who labour (for future happiness) he is greatest who lives well in the household state
kural.kannan_exp: One who leads a normal and intimate family life, is far ahead of those who seek other priorities.

kural.pope_couplet: Others it sets upon their way, itself from virtue ne'er declines;Than stern ascetics' pains such life domestic brighter shines
kural.pope_exp: The householder who, not swerving from virtue, helps the ascetic in his way, endures more than those who endure penance
kural.kannan_exp: If one lives by the right virtues and assists others to do the same, such a family life is better than the penance of saints

kural.pope_couplet: The life domestic rightly bears true virtue's name;That other too, if blameless found, due praise may claim
kural.pope_exp: The marriage state is truly called virtue The other state is also good, if others do not reproach it
kural.kannan_exp: True virtue is to lead a harmonious family life; it is even better if it is beyond others’ blame.

kural.pope_couplet: Who shares domestic life, by household virtues graced,Shall, mid the Gods, in heaven who dwell, be placed
kural.pope_exp: He who on earth has lived in the conjugal state as he should live, will be placed among the Gods who dwell in heaven
kural.kannan_exp: One who lives worldly life the way it ought to be lived will be treated on par with the Gods inhabiting the heavens.

kural.pope_couplet: As doth the house beseem, she shows her wifely dignity;As doth her husband's wealth befit, she spends: help - meet is she
kural.pope_exp: She who has the excellence of home virtues, and can expend within the means of her husband, is a help in the domestic state
kural.kannan_exp: A spouse who possesses virtues required for the family and spends within the means is the ideal life partner.

kural.pope_couplet: If household excellence be wanting in the wife,Howe'er with splendour lived, all worthless is the life
kural.pope_exp: If the wife be devoid of domestic excellence, whatever (other) greatness be possessed, the conjugal state, is nothing
kural.kannan_exp: If your spouse doesnt possess the virtues needed for married life, whatever else you possess in life is irrelevant.

kural.pope_couplet: There is no lack within the house, where wife in worth excels,There is no luck within the house, where wife dishonoured dwells
kural.pope_exp: If his wife be eminent (in virtue), what does (that man) not possess ? If she be without excellence, what does (he) possess ?
kural.kannan_exp: If your spouse has the qualities suited for family life, what is it that you dont have? If not, what is it that you have?

kural.pope_couplet: If woman might of chastity retain,What choicer treasure doth the world contain
kural.pope_exp: What is more excellent than a wife, if she possess the stability of chastity ?
kural.kannan_exp: If your spouse is strongly virtuous, can there be anything worthier that your spouse?

kural.pope_couplet: No God adoring, low she bends before her lord;Then rising, serves: the rain falls instant at her word
kural.pope_exp: If she, who does not worship God, but who rising worships her husband, say, "let it rain," it will rain
kural.kannan_exp: Rain will pour instantly at the order of a wife who prays not to God but to her husband.

kural.pope_couplet: Who guards herself, for husband's comfort cares, her household's fame,In perfect wise with sleepless soul preserves, -give her a woman's name
kural.pope_exp: She is a wife who unweariedly guards herself, takes care of her husband, and preserves an unsullied fame
kural.kannan_exp: A woman not only protects herself, but tirelessly takes care of her husband and preserves the family reputation.

kural.pope_couplet: Of what avail is watch and ward?Honour's woman's safest guard
kural.pope_exp: What avails the guard of a prison ? The chief guard of a woman is her chastity
kural.kannan_exp: Is it of any use to possess women by imposing physical barriers? A woman will remain virtuous only on her own volition.

kural.pope_couplet: If wife be wholly true to him who gained her as his bride,Great glory gains she in the world where gods bliss abide
kural.pope_exp: If women shew reverence to their husbands, they will obtain great excellence in the world where the gods flourish
kural.kannan_exp: If a woman gets a spouse with great character, she will enjoy the glory of heaven on earth.

kural.pope_couplet: Who have not spouses that in virtue's praise delight,They lion-like can never walk in scorner's sight
kural.pope_exp: The man whose wife seeks not the praise (of chastity) cannot walk with lion-like stately step, before those who revile them
kural.kannan_exp: Those who dont have respectable family lives, will not be able to stride with a lion-like pride before their opponents.

kural.pope_couplet: The house's 'blessing', men pronounce the house-wife excellent;The gain of blessed children is its goodly ornament
kural.pope_exp: The excellence of a wife is the good of her husband; and good children are the jewels of that goodness
kural.kannan_exp: A great harmonious married life is a boon; having good offsprings adds luster to it.

kural.pope_couplet: Of all that men acquire, we know not any greater gain,Than that which by the birth of learned children men obtain
kural.pope_exp: Among all the benefits that may be acquired, we know no greater benefit than the acquisition of intelligent children
kural.kannan_exp: Other than having children who are wise enough to know what needs to be known, there is no other treasure that I value more.

kural.pope_couplet: Who children gain, that none reproach, of virtuous worth,No evils touch them, through the sev'n-fold maze of birth
kural.pope_exp: The evils of the seven births shall not touch those who abtain children of a good disposition, free from vice
kural.kannan_exp: No harm will befell one for even seven births, if one gives birth to children who have irreproachable character.

kural.pope_couplet: 'Man's children are his fortune,' say the wise;From each one's deeds his varied fortunes rise
kural.pope_exp: Men will call their sons their wealth, because it flows to them through the deeds which they (sons) perform on their behalf
kural.kannan_exp: One’s children are defined as one’s wealth; the wealth that the children make will be through their own deeds.

kural.pope_couplet: Than God's ambrosia sweeter far the food before men laid,In which the little hands of children of their own have play'd
kural.pope_exp: The rice in which the little hand of their children has dabbled will be far sweeter (to the parent) than ambrosia
kural.kannan_exp: The porridge stirred playfully with the tiny hands of one’s children is sweeter than nectar.

kural.pope_couplet: To patent sweet the touch of children dear;Their voice is sweetest music to his ear
kural.pope_exp: The touch of children gives pleasure to the body, and the hearing of their words, pleasure to the ear
kural.kannan_exp: The tender skin of one’s children is joyous to touch; their sweet voices rapturous to hear.

kural.pope_couplet: 'The pipe is sweet,' 'the lute is sweet,' by them't will be averred,Who music of their infants' lisping lips have never heard
kural.pope_exp: "The pipe is sweet, the lute is sweet," say those who have not heard the prattle of their own children
kural.kannan_exp: Only those who don’t listen to their baby’s sweet babble will claim that a flute or yaazh sounds melodious.

kural.pope_couplet: Sire greatest boon on son confers, who makes him meet,In councils of the wise to fill the highest seat
kural.pope_exp: The benefit which a father should confer on his son is to give him precedence in the assembly of the learned
kural.kannan_exp: The duty of a father towards his children is to give them a headstart in knowledge over the best of scholars.

kural.pope_couplet: Their children's wisdom greater than their own confessed,Through the wide world is sweet to every human breast
kural.pope_exp: That their children should possess knowledge is more pleasing to all men of this great earth than to themselves
kural.kannan_exp: All living creatures on this earth feel prouder when their children are smarter than themselves.

kural.pope_couplet: When mother hears him named 'fulfill'd of wisdom's lore,'Far greater joy she feels, than when her son she bore
kural.pope_exp: The mother who hears her son called "a wise man" will rejoice more than she did at his birth
kural.kannan_exp: A mother feels more ecstatic to hear her son being praised as a noble scholar than when the son was born.

kural.pope_couplet: To sire, what best requital can by grateful child be done?To make men say, 'What merit gained the father such a son?'
kural.pope_exp: (So to act) that it may be said "by what great penance did his father beget him," is the benefit which a son should render to his father
kural.kannan_exp: The duty of a son towards his father is to make others wonder what great deeds did the father do to deserve such a son.

kural.pope_couplet: And is there bar that can even love restrain?The tiny tear shall make the lover's secret plain
kural.pope_exp: Is there any fastening that can shut in love ? Tears of the affectionate will publish the love that is within
kural.kannan_exp: Can there be a latch to lock in and hide love? It will reveal itself through tears when a loved one is in trouble.

kural.pope_couplet: The loveless to themselves belong alone;The loving men are others' to the very bone
kural.pope_exp: Those who are destitute of love appropriate all they have to themselves; but those who possess love consider even their bones to belong to others
kural.kannan_exp: Loveless people hold everything to themselves. Those who are filled with love bear even their bones for others.

kural.pope_couplet: Of precious soul with body's flesh and bone,The union yields one fruit, the life of love alone
kural.pope_exp: They say that the union of soul and body in man is the fruit of the union of love and virtue (in a former birth)
kural.kannan_exp: Precious life is associated with the body Since love is associated with the way of life, they say.

kural.pope_couplet: From love fond yearning springs for union sweet of minds;And that the bond of rare excelling friendship binds
kural.pope_exp: Love begets desire: and that (desire) begets the immeasureable excellence of friendship
kural.kannan_exp: Love yields affection for all, which leads to invaluable friendships.

kural.pope_couplet: Sweetness on earth and rarest bliss above,These are the fruits of tranquil life of love
kural.pope_exp: These are the fruits of tranquil life of love
kural.kannan_exp: The honour for those who found joy in this world Is the result of leading a life of love, it’s said.

kural.pope_couplet: The unwise deem love virtue only can sustain,It also helps the man who evil would restrain
kural.pope_exp: The ignorant say that love is an ally to virtue only, but it is also a help to get out of vice
kural.kannan_exp: The ignorant think that love is needed only for righteous deeds; they know not that love is an ally for bravery too.

kural.pope_couplet: As sun's fierce ray dries up the boneless things,So loveless beings virtue's power to nothing brings
kural.pope_exp: Virtue will burn up the soul which is without love, even as the sun burns up the creature which is without bone, ie worms
kural.kannan_exp: A life without love will be stung by the righteous conscience like a body without bones that is burnt by the sun.

kural.pope_couplet: The loveless soul, the very joys of life may know,When flowers, in barren soil, on sapless trees, shall blow
kural.pope_exp: The domestic state of that man whose mind is without love is like the flourishing of a withered tree upon the parched desert
kural.kannan_exp: A life without love in the heart is as futile as a dried-up tree blossoming in a desert.

kural.pope_couplet: Though every outward part complete, the body's fitly framed;What good, when soul within, of love devoid, lies halt and maimed
kural.pope_exp: Of what avail are all the external members (of the body) to those who are destitute of love, the internal member
kural.kannan_exp: What useful things can external body parts do, if the heart is devoid of love.

kural.pope_couplet: Bodies of loveless men are bony framework clad with skin;Then is the body seat of life, when love resides within
kural.pope_exp: That body alone which is inspired with love contains a living soul: if void of it, (the body) is bone overlaid with skin
kural.kannan_exp: Only a person who follows the path of love, is in a state of living; else it is just a skeleton dressed with skin.

kural.pope_couplet: All household cares and course of daily life have this in viewGuests to receive with courtesy, and kindly acts to do
kural.pope_exp: The whole design of living in the domestic state and laying up (property) is (to be able) to exercise the benevolence of hospitality
kural.kannan_exp: The purpose of nurturing wealth and leading a family life, is to be able to be hospitable to guests.

kural.pope_couplet: Though food of immortality should crown the board,Feasting alone, the guests without unfed, is thing abhorred
kural.pope_exp: It is not fit that one should wish his guests to be outside (his house) even though he were eating the food of immortality
kural.kannan_exp: Even if you have nectar that will assure immortality, it is not appreciable to dine alone, leaving the guests out.

kural.pope_couplet: Each day he tends the coming guest with kindly care;Painless, unfailing plenty shall his household share
kural.pope_exp: The domestic life of the man that daily entertains the guests who come to him shall not be laid waste by poverty
kural.kannan_exp: One who is hospitable to guests everyday never suffers because of that.

kural.pope_couplet: With smiling face he entertains each virtuous guest,'Fortune' with gladsome mind shall in his dwelling rest
kural.pope_exp: Lakshmi with joyous mind shall dwell in the house of that man who, with cheerful countenance, entertains the good as guests
kural.kannan_exp: The Goddess of wealth will reside happily with someone who attends to his guests with a smile on the face.

kural.pope_couplet: Who first regales his guest, and then himself supplies,O'er all his fields, unsown, shall plenteous harvests rise
kural.pope_exp: Is it necessary to sow the field of the man who, having feasted his guests, eats what may remain ?
kural.kannan_exp: Does one even need to sow his field, if he always eats only what remains after feeding his guests?

kural.pope_couplet: The guest arrived he tends, the coming guest expects to see;To those in heavenly homes that dwell a welcome guest is he
kural.pope_exp: He who, having entertained the guests that have come, looks out for others who may yet come, will be a welcome guest to the inhabitants of heaven
kural.kannan_exp: One who is hospitable to his guests, and when they leave, awaits his next guests, will be a welcome-guest in the heavens.

kural.pope_couplet: To reckon up the fruit of kindly deeds were all in vain;Their worth is as the worth of guests you entertain
kural.pope_exp: The advantages of benevolence cannot be measured; the measure (of the virtue) of the guests (entertained) is the only measure
kural.kannan_exp: We can’t quantify the benefits of hospitality; it is limited only by the quality of the guests.

kural.pope_couplet: With pain they guard their stores, yet 'All forlorn are we,' they'll cry,Who cherish not their guests, nor kindly help supply
kural.pope_exp: Those who have taken no part in the benevolence of hospitality shall (at length lament) saying, "we have laboured and laid up wealth and are now without support."
kural.kannan_exp: Those who dont take up hospitality as a spiritual ritual, will later repent that they have lost the wealth they loved.

kural.pope_couplet: To turn from guests is penury, though worldly goods abound;'Tis senseless folly, only with the senseless found
kural.pope_exp: That stupidity which excercises no hospitality is poverty in the midst of wealth It is the property of the stupid
kural.kannan_exp: There are fools who choose to be poor despite possessing wealth, by not being hospitable to guests.

kural.pope_couplet: The flower of 'Anicha' withers away, If you do but its fragrance inhale;If the face of the host cold welcome convey, The guest's heart within him will fail
kural.pope_exp: As the Anicham flower fades in smelling, so fades the guest when the face is turned away
kural.kannan_exp: The flower, anicham, shrivels when it is smelt. A guest will wilt if the host’s face betrays the slightest twitch.

kural.pope_couplet: Pleasant words are words with all pervading love that burn;Words from his guileless mouth who can the very truth discern
kural.pope_exp: Sweet words are those which imbued with love and free from deceit flow from the mouth of the virtuous
kural.kannan_exp: The words uttered by enlightened scholars will only be kind words carrying love and no malice.

kural.pope_couplet: A pleasant word with beaming smile's preferred,Even to gifts with liberal heart conferred
kural.pope_exp: Sweet speech, with a cheerful countenance is better than a gift made with a joyous mind
kural.kannan_exp: To be someone who speaks sweet words with a smile is even better than being philanthropic with a happy heart.

kural.pope_couplet: With brightly beaming smile, and kindly light of loving eye,And heart sincere, to utter pleasant words is charity
kural.pope_exp: Sweet speech, flowing from the heart (uttered) with a cheerful countenance and a sweet look, is true virtue
kural.kannan_exp: To look at someone with kindness, to smile at them and to say pleasant words, is a nice virtue.

kural.pope_couplet: The men of pleasant speech that gladness breathe around,Through indigence shall never sorrow's prey be found
kural.pope_exp: Sorrow-increasing poverty shall not come upon those who use towards all, pleasure-increasing sweetness of speech
kural.kannan_exp: Painful poverty will not afflict someone who speaks only pleasant words to everyone.

kural.pope_couplet: Humility with pleasant speech to man on earth,Is choice adornment; all besides is nothing worth
kural.pope_exp: Humility and sweetness of speech are the ornaments of man; all others are not (ornaments)
kural.kannan_exp: Humility and pleasant words are the true jewels for anyone and not anything else.

kural.pope_couplet: Who seeks out good, words from his lips of sweetness flow;In him the power of vice declines, and virtues grow
kural.pope_exp: If a man, while seeking to speak usefully, speaks also sweetly, his sins will diminish and his virtue increase
kural.kannan_exp: If one seeks and speaks pleasant words that cause good all around, righteousness resides and harm recedes.

kural.pope_couplet: The words of sterling sense, to rule of right that strict adhere,To virtuous action prompting, blessings yield in every sphere
kural.pope_exp: That speech which, while imparting benefits ceases not to please, will yield righteousness (for this world) and merit (for the next world)
kural.kannan_exp: Speech that is inseparable from sweetness will yield just-consequences and will reflect right virtues.

kural.pope_couplet: Sweet kindly words, from meanness free, delight of heart,In world to come and in this world impart
kural.pope_exp: Sweet speech, free from harm to others, will give pleasure both in this world and in the next
kural.kannan_exp: A sweet word, said without the slightest spite, will provide delight in this life and the next.

kural.pope_couplet: Who sees the pleasure kindly speech affords,Why makes he use of harsh, repellant words
kural.pope_exp: Why does he use harsh words, who sees the pleasure which sweet speech yields ?
kural.kannan_exp: Having seen the sweet benefits of pleasant words, why should one utter harsh words?

kural.pope_couplet: When pleasant words are easy, bitter words to use,Is, leaving sweet ripe fruit, the sour unripe to choose
kural.pope_exp: To say disagreeable things when agreeable are at hand is like eating unripe fruit when there is ripe
kural.kannan_exp: To be nasty when you can say nice words, is like tasting an unripe fruit when you have a ripe one.

kural.pope_couplet: Assistance given by those who ne'er received our aid,Is debt by gift of heaven and earth but poorly paid
kural.pope_exp: (The gift of) heaven and earth is not an equivalent for a benefit which is conferred where none had been received
kural.kannan_exp: A favour done, not as return for another, is more valuable than heaven and earth put together.

kural.pope_couplet: A timely benefit, -though thing of little worth,The gift itself, -in excellence transcends the earth
kural.pope_exp: A favour conferred in the time of need, though it be small (in itself), is (in value) much larger than the world
kural.kannan_exp: A timely favour, however trivial its material value is, is invaluable.

kural.pope_couplet: Kindness shown by those who weigh not what the return may be:When you ponder right its merit, 'Tis vaster than the sea
kural.pope_exp: If we weigh the excellence of a benefit which is conferred without weighing the return, it is larger than the sea
kural.kannan_exp: If we delve into the real impact of a favour, done without calculating the returns, it is vaster than the ocean.

kural.pope_couplet: Each benefit to those of actions' fruit who rightly deem,Though small as millet-seed, as palm-tree vast will seem
kural.pope_exp: Though the benefit conferred be as small as a millet seed, those who know its advantage will consider it as large as a palmyra fruit
kural.kannan_exp: Those who know the value of a favour, will not evaluate its worth, even if a favour done is a minor one. Those who know the true value of a favour, will see for the quantum of favour, a tree, where there was a grain.

kural.pope_couplet: The kindly aid's extent is of its worth no measure true;Its worth is as the worth of him to whom the act you do
kural.pope_exp: The benefit itself is not the measure of the benefit; the worth of those who have received it is its measure
kural.kannan_exp: A favour returned, is not to be based on quantum of favour done, but on the magnanimity of the person who did the favour.

kural.pope_couplet: Kindness of men of stainless soul remember evermoreForsake thou never friends who were thy stay in sorrow sore
kural.pope_exp: Forsake not the friendship of those who have been your staff in adversity Forget not be benevolence of the blameless
kural.kannan_exp: Never forget your ties with a flawless person; never forego the friendship of those who stood by you during a distress.

kural.pope_couplet: Through all seven worlds, in seven-fold birth, Remains in mem'ry of the wiseFriendship of those who wiped on earth, The tears of sorrow from their eyes
kural.pope_exp: (The wise) will remember throughout their seven-fold births the love of those who have wiped away their affliction
kural.kannan_exp: One would remember the friendship of those who helped overcome a distress, forever, even if there are seven births.

kural.pope_couplet: 'Tis never good to let the thought of good things done thee pass away;Of things not good, 'tis good to rid thy memory that very day
kural.pope_exp: It is not good to forget a benefit; it is good to forget an injury even in the very moment (in which it is inflicted)
kural.kannan_exp: It is not right to forget the help rendered by someone; it is virtuous to forget any harm, the moment it is done.

kural.pope_couplet: Effaced straightway is deadliest injury,By thought of one kind act in days gone by
kural.pope_exp: Though one inflict an injury great as murder, it will perish before the thought of one benefit (formerly) conferred
kural.kannan_exp: Even if a person commits murderous injury, it will be overlooked if he has done one good deed earlier.

kural.pope_couplet: Who every good have killed, may yet destruction flee;Who 'benefit' has killed, that man shall ne'er 'scape free
kural.pope_exp: He who has killed every virtue may yet escape; there is no escape for him who has killed a benefit
kural.kannan_exp: There is salvation for faltering on any virtue but not for ingratitude.

kural.pope_couplet: If justice, failing not, its quality maintain,Giving to each his due, -'tis man's one highest gain
kural.pope_exp: That equity which consists in acting with equal regard to each of (the three) divisions of men [enemies, strangers and friends] is a pre-eminent virtue
kural.kannan_exp: Neutrality is a great virtue when one practices impartiality, unfailingly, towards all sections. (Foes, friends, strangers)

kural.pope_couplet: The just man's wealth unwasting shall endure,And to his race a lasting joy ensure
kural.pope_exp: The wealth of the man of rectitude will not perish, but will bring happiness also to his posterity
kural.kannan_exp: The wealth of one who has a balanced view, will remain intact and will last for the next generations.

kural.pope_couplet: Though only good it seem to give, yet gainBy wrong acquired, not e'en one day retain
kural.pope_exp: Forsake in the very moment (of acquisition) that gain which, though it should bring advantage, is without equity
kural.kannan_exp: Even if some good comes out of the gains generated by being unfair, desist from making that gain.

kural.pope_couplet: Who just or unjust lived shall soon appear:By each one's offspring shall the truth be clear
kural.pope_exp: The worthy and unworthy may be known by the existence or otherwise of good offsprings
kural.kannan_exp: Whether a person has been just or unjust in life, will be ascertained by the nature of offsprings left behind.

kural.pope_couplet: The gain and loss in life are not mere accident;Just mind inflexible is sages' ornament
kural.pope_exp: Loss and gain come not without cause; it is the ornament of the wise to preserve evenness of mind (under both)
kural.kannan_exp: Ups and downs in life are inevitable; noble scholars are embellished by not letting their hearts vacillate in either case.

kural.pope_couplet: If, right deserting, heart to evil turn,Let man impending ruin's sign discern
kural.pope_exp: Let him whose mind departing from equity commits sin well consider thus within himself, "I shall perish."
kural.kannan_exp: When the heart falters to think unfairly, be alerted that you are on course for ruination.

kural.pope_couplet: The man who justly lives, tenacious of the right,In low estate is never low to wise man's sight
kural.pope_exp: The great will not regard as poverty the low estate of that man who dwells in the virtue of equity
kural.kannan_exp: The world will not think ill of one who has stumbled into poverty because of being fair and righteous.

kural.pope_couplet: To stand, like balance-rod that level hangs and rightly weighs,With calm unbiassed equity of soul, is sages' praise
kural.pope_exp: To incline to neither side, but to rest impartial as the even-fixed scale is the ornament of the wise
kural.kannan_exp: Like a weighing scale that is balanced and sways correctly, the grace of noble scholars lies in dispassionate assessment.

kural.pope_couplet: Inflexibility in word is righteousness,If men inflexibility of soul possess
kural.pope_exp: Freedom from obliquity of speech is rectitude, if there be (corresponding) freedom from bias of mind
kural.kannan_exp: It is righteous to speak words that are not deviant; such words are a result of unbiased thoughts that are not deviant.

kural.pope_couplet: As thriving trader is the trader known,Who guards another's interests as his own
kural.pope_exp: The true merchandize of merchants is to guard and do by the things of others as they do by their own
kural.kannan_exp: Responsible business is when a business-person, caringly, deploys other people’s money as one’s own.

kural.pope_couplet: Control of self does man conduct to bliss th' immortals share;Indulgence leads to deepest night, and leaves him there
kural.pope_exp: Self-control will place (a man) among the Gods; the want of it will drive (him) into the thickest darkness (of hell)
kural.kannan_exp: Restraint will result in a place among the divine; lack of it will lead to utter darkness.

kural.pope_couplet: Guard thou as wealth the power of self-control;Than this no greater gain to living soul
kural.pope_exp: Let self-control be guarded as a treasure; there is no greater source of good for man than that
kural.kannan_exp: Preserve your restraint as you would preserve your wealth; for humans, there is no treasure more precious.

kural.pope_couplet: If versed in wisdom's lore by virtue's law you self restrainYour self-repression known will yield you glory's gain
kural.pope_exp: Knowing that self-control is knowledge, if a man should control himself, in the prescribed course, such self-control will bring him distinction among the wise
kural.kannan_exp: The greatness of one, who is wise and follows the right path by being restrained, will be recognized and appreciated.

kural.pope_couplet: In his station, all unswerving, if man self subdue,Greater he than mountain proudly rising to the view
kural.pope_exp: More lofty than a mountain will be the greatness of that man who without swerving from his domestic state, controls himself
kural.kannan_exp: The stature of one, who doesn’t diverge from the right path and remains restrained, will belittle a mountain.

kural.pope_couplet: To all humility is goodly grace; but chief to themWith fortune blessed, -'tis fortune's diadem
kural.pope_exp: Humility is good in all; but especially in the rich it is (the excellence of) higher riches
kural.kannan_exp: Humility is a good quality in everyone; in particular, for the wealthy, it is like their wealth.

kural.pope_couplet: Like tortoise, who the five restrainsIn one, through seven world bliss obtains
kural.pope_exp: Should one throughout a single birth, like a tortoise keep in his five senses, the fruit of it will prove a safe-guard to him throughout the seven-fold births.
kural.kannan_exp: If one can restrain his five senses, like a tortoise that retreats into its single shell, it will be a protection through seven births.

kural.pope_couplet: Whate'er they fail to guard, o'er lips men guard should keep;If not, through fault of tongue, they bitter tears shall weep
kural.pope_exp: Whatever besides you leave unguarded, guard your tongue; otherwise errors of speech and the consequent misery will ensue
kural.kannan_exp: Even if nothing else can be restrained, one must control his tongue; if not, he will suffer because of the harm inflicted by his words.

kural.pope_couplet: Though some small gain of good it seem to bring,The evil word is parent still of evil thing
kural.pope_exp: If a man's speech be productive of a single evil, all the good by him will be turned into evil
kural.kannan_exp: Even if there is one harm caused by harsh words, all the good caused by other virtuous deeds will also be seen as evil.

kural.pope_couplet: In flesh by fire inflamed, nature may thoroughly heal the sore;In soul by tongue inflamed, the ulcer healeth never more
kural.pope_exp: The wound which has been burnt in by fire may heal, but a wound burnt in by the tongue will never heal
kural.kannan_exp: A wound caused by fire will heal inside; a scar caused by the tongue never heals.

kural.pope_couplet: Who learns restraint, and guards his soul from wrath,Virtue, a timely aid, attends his path
kural.pope_exp: Virtue, seeking for an opportunity, will come into the path of that man who, possessed of learning and self-control, guards himself against anger
kural.kannan_exp: Virtue will wait for the moment to adorn one, who controls anger, learns all there is to learn and exercises restraint.

kural.pope_couplet: 'Decorum' gives especial excellence; with greater care'Decorum' should men guard than life, which all men share
kural.pope_exp: Propriety of conduct leads to eminence, it should therefore be preserved more carefully than life
kural.kannan_exp: Propriety confers prominence; hence, propriety is cherished more than existence.

kural.pope_couplet: Searching, duly watching, learning, 'decorum' still we find;Man's only aid; toiling, guard thou this with watchful mind
kural.pope_exp: Let propriety of conduct be laboriously preserved and guarded; though one know and practise and excel in many virtues, that will be an eminent aid
kural.kannan_exp: Take painstaking effort to preserve propriety; after researching all there is to, one can conclude, it is the best ally.

kural.pope_couplet: 'Decorum's' true nobility on earth;'Indecorum's' issue is ignoble birth
kural.pope_exp: Propriety of conduct is true greatness of birth, and impropriety will sink into a mean birth
kural.kannan_exp: Class is determined by propriety of conduct; impropriety will lead to being considered part of an ignoble class.

kural.pope_couplet: Though he forget, the Brahman may regain his Vedic lore;Failing in 'decorum due,' birthright's gone for evermore
kural.pope_exp: A Brahman though he should forget the Vedas may recover it by reading; but, if he fail in propriety of conduct even his high birth will be destroyed
kural.kannan_exp: One can relearn if he forgets the scriptures; but, a brahmin ceases to be one, when he strays from his decorum.

kural.pope_couplet: The envious soul in life no rich increase of blessing gains,So man of 'due decorum' void no dignity obtains
kural.pope_exp: Just as the envious man will be without wealth, so will the man of destitute of propriety of conduct be without greatness
kural.kannan_exp: A person who has envy has no wealth; a person who has no decorum has no growth.

kural.pope_couplet: The strong of soul no jot abate of 'strict decorum's' laws,Knowing that 'due decorum's' breach foulest disgrace will cause
kural.pope_exp: Those firm in mind will not slacken in their observance of the proprieties of life, knowing, as they do, the misery that flows from the transgression from them
kural.kannan_exp: The strong-willed don’t shrivel their propriety, knowing the suffering inflicted by impropriety.

kural.pope_couplet: 'Tis source of dignity when 'true decorum' is preserved;Who break 'decorum's' rules endure e'en censures undeserved
kural.pope_exp: From propriety of conduct men obtain greatness; from impropriety comes insufferable disgrace
kural.kannan_exp: One attains eminence through decorum; one attains unprecedented infamy due to indecorum.

kural.pope_couplet: 'Decorum true' observed a seed of good will be;'Decorum's breach' will sorrow yield eternally
kural.pope_exp: Propriety of conduct is the seed of virtue; impropriety will ever cause sorrow
kural.kannan_exp: Good conduct becomes the seed for goodwill and impropriety always yields agony.

kural.pope_couplet: It cannot be that they who 'strict decorum's' law fulfil,E'en in forgetful mood, should utter words of ill
kural.pope_exp: Those who study propriety of conduct will not speak evil, even forgetfully
kural.kannan_exp: Those who practice propriety find it impossible to utter harmful words even forgetfully.

kural.pope_couplet: Who know not with the world in harmony to dwell,May many things have learned, but nothing well
kural.pope_exp: Those who know not how to act agreeably to the world, though they have learnt many things, are still ignorant
kural.kannan_exp: Those who don’t learn to abide by the decorous norms of the society, even if well-read, are unwise.

kural.pope_couplet: Who laws of virtue and possession's rights have known,Indulge no foolish love of her by right another's own
kural.pope_exp: The folly of desiring her who is the property of another will not be found in those who know (the attributes of) virtue and (the rights of) property
kural.kannan_exp: The indiscretion of desiring another’s wife will not be found in those who are enlightened about virtue and possession.

kural.pope_couplet: No fools, of all that stand from virtue's pale shut out,Like those who longing lurk their neighbour's gate without
kural.pope_exp: Among all those who stand on the outside of virtue, there are no greater fools than those who stand outside their neighbour's door
kural.kannan_exp: Of all those who have been beyond the boundaries of morality, there are no greater imbeciles than those who go after another’s wife.

kural.pope_couplet: They're numbered with the dead, e'en while they live, -how otherwise?With wife of sure confiding friend who evil things devise
kural.pope_exp: Certainly they are no better than dead men who desire evil towards the wife of those who
kural.kannan_exp: A person is not any better than the dead, when he indulges in adultery with the wife of another who trusts him.

kural.pope_couplet: How great soe'er they be, what gain have they of life,Who, not a whit reflecting, seek a neighbour's wife
kural.pope_exp: However great one may be, what does it avail if, without at all considering his guilt, he goes unto the wife of another ?
kural.kannan_exp: What worth is one’s reputation, however big it is,when, without considering the least bit, he has an affair with another’s wife.

kural.pope_couplet: 'Mere triflel' saying thus, invades the home, so he ensuresA gain of guilt that deathless aye endures
kural.pope_exp: He who thinks lightly of going into the wife of another acquires guilt that will abide with him imperishably and for ever
kural.kannan_exp: One who indulges in adultery with another’s wife,considering it to be simple (without anticipating the consequences), will beget a blame that will stay forever.

kural.pope_couplet: Who home ivades, from him pass nevermore,Hatred and sin, fear, foul disgrace; these four
kural.pope_exp: Hatred, sin, fear, disgrace; these four will never leave him who goes in to his neighbour's wife
kural.kannan_exp: Animosity, sin, fear and vengeance – these four will never leave one with a liaison with another’s wife.

kural.pope_couplet: Who sees the wife, another's own, with no desiring eyeIn sure domestic bliss he dwelleth ever virtuously
kural.pope_exp: He who desires not the womanhood of her who should walk according to the will of another will be praised as a virtuous house-holder
kural.kannan_exp: One, who leads a righteous family life, will not crave the feminine grace of another’s wife.

kural.pope_couplet: Manly excellence, that looks not on another's wife,Is not virtue merely, 'tis full 'propriety' of life
kural.pope_exp: That noble manliness which looks not at the wife of another is the virtue and dignity of the great
kural.kannan_exp: The magnanimous machismo of not coveting another’s wife is, for noble scholars, an exalted virtue and decent decorum.

kural.pope_couplet: Who 're good indeed, on earth begirt by ocean's gruesome tide?The men who touch not her that is another's bride
kural.pope_exp: Is it asked, "who are those who shall obtain good in this world surrounded by the terror-producing sea ?" Those who touch not the shoulder of her who belongs to another
kural.kannan_exp: Whosoever deserves all the good in this world, surrounded by the fearsome ocean, will never surrender on the shoulders of a woman who belongs to another.

kural.pope_couplet: Though virtue's bounds he pass, and evil deeds hath wrought;At least, 'tis good if neighbour's wife he covet not
kural.pope_exp: Though a man perform no virtuous deeds and commit (every) vice, it will be well if he desire not the womanhood of her who is within the limit (of the house) of another
kural.kannan_exp: Even if one is unrighteous and does many a misdeed, he should, atleast, not fall for the feminine charm of another’s wife.

kural.pope_couplet: As earth bears up the men who delve into her breast,To bear with scornful men of virtues is the best
kural.pope_exp: To bear with those who revile us, just as the earth bears up those who dig it, is the first of virtues
kural.kannan_exp: Like the earth that bears even those who till it, supreme virtue is to be patient with one’s deriders.

kural.pope_couplet: Forgiving trespasses is good always;Forgetting them hath even higher praise;
kural.pope_exp: Bear with reproach even when you can retaliate; but to forget it will be still better than that
kural.kannan_exp: One should always tolerate a transgression; it is even better to forget it.

kural.pope_couplet: The sorest poverty is bidding guest unfed depart;The mightiest might to bear with men of foolish heart
kural.pope_exp: To neglect hospitality is poverty of poverty To bear with the ignorant is might of might
kural.kannan_exp: Turning away a guest is the most abject poverty; enduring the excesses of a moron is the mightiest might.

kural.pope_couplet: Seek'st thou honour never tarnished to retain;So must thou patience, guarding evermore, maintain
kural.pope_exp: If you desire that greatness should never leave, you preserve in your conduct the exercise of patience
kural.kannan_exp: If you want to lead an unabated fulfilling life, you have to preserve and practice forbearance.

kural.pope_couplet: Who wreak their wrath as worthless are despised;Who patiently forbear as gold are prized
kural.pope_exp: (The wise) will not at all esteem the resentful They will esteem the patient just as the gold which they lay up with care
kural.kannan_exp: One who retaliates is not held in high regard; one who is patient is precious as gold.

kural.pope_couplet: Who wreak their wrath have pleasure for a day;Who bear have praise till earth shall pass away
kural.pope_exp: The pleasure of the resentful continues for a day The praise of the patient will continue until (the final destruction of) the world
kural.kannan_exp: Those who retaliate rarely rejoice for a day; the repute of the patient remains till the end of the world.

kural.pope_couplet: Though others work thee ill, thus shalt thou blessing reap;Grieve for their sin, thyself from vicious action keep
kural.pope_exp: Though others inflict injuries on you, yet compassionating the evil (that will come upon them) it will be well not to do them anything contrary to virtue
kural.kannan_exp: Even if an untoward evil is done unto you, it is better not to resent and do an unrighteous deed.

kural.pope_couplet: With overweening pride when men with injuries assail,By thine own righteous dealing shalt thou mightily prevail
kural.pope_exp: Let a man by patience overcome those who through pride commit excesses
kural.kannan_exp: Defeat a person who has, out of arrogance, done you harm, by your forbearance.

kural.pope_couplet: They who transgressors' evil words endureWith patience, are as stern ascetics pure
kural.pope_exp: Those who bear with the uncourteous speech of the insolent are as pure as the ascetics
kural.kannan_exp: One who, patiently, bears the harsh words of a transgressor, is purer than a puritan.

kural.pope_couplet: Though 'great' we deem the men that fast and suffer pain,Who others' bitter words endure, the foremost place obtain
kural.pope_exp: Those who endure abstinence from food are great, next to those who endure the uncourteous speech of others
kural.kannan_exp: Great ascetics who conquer hunger, by fasting, are inferior to those who patiently endure the harsh words of others.

kural.pope_couplet: As 'strict decorum's' laws, that all men bind,Let each regard unenvying grace of mind
kural.pope_exp: Let a man esteem that disposition which is free from envy in the same manner as propriety of conduct
kural.kannan_exp: One should make it a righteous way of life, to hold no envy in his heart.

kural.pope_couplet: If man can learn to envy none on earth,'Tis richest gift, -beyond compare its worth
kural.pope_exp: Amongst all attainable excellences there is none equal to that of being free from envy towords others
kural.kannan_exp: Not being envious of anybody is a rich reward; there is nothing that can match it.

kural.pope_couplet: Nor wealth nor virtue does that man desire 'tis plain,Whom others' wealth delights not, feeling envious pain
kural.pope_exp: Of him who instead of rejoicing in the wealth of others, envies it, it will be said "he neither desires virtue not wealth."
kural.kannan_exp: One who, in his envy, doesn’t appreciate the wealth of others, is known not to value virtue and his own wealth.

kural.pope_couplet: The wise through envy break not virtue's laws,Knowing ill-deeds of foul disgrace the cause
kural.pope_exp: (The wise) knowing the misery that comes from transgression will not through envy commit unrighteous deeds
kural.kannan_exp: Those who know of the ills inflicted by envy, will not do anything evil out of envy.

kural.pope_couplet: Envy they have within! Enough to seat their fate!Though foemen fail, envy can ruin consummate
kural.pope_exp: To those who cherish envy that is enough Though free from enemies that (envy) will bring destruction
kural.kannan_exp: For destruction to be caused, there is no need for enemies; if one has envy, it will suffice.

kural.pope_couplet: Who scans good gifts to others given with envious eye,His kin, with none to clothe or feed them, surely die
kural.pope_exp: He who is envious at a gift (made to another) will with his relations utterly perish destitute of food and rainment
kural.kannan_exp: One who feels envious of the wealth given away as charity, will have even his kin suffer without anything to wear and eat.

kural.pope_couplet: From envious man good fortune's goddess turns away,Grudging him good, and points him out misfortune's prey
kural.pope_exp: Lakshmi envying (the prosperity) of the envious man will depart and introduce him to her sister
kural.kannan_exp: Sridevi, goddess of wealth, will despise a jealous person and direct him to her sister, Moodevi, goddess of poverty.

kural.pope_couplet: Envy, embodied ill, incomparable bane,Good fortune slays, and soul consigns to fiery pain
kural.pope_exp: Envy will destroy (a man's) wealth (in his world) and drive him into the pit of fire (in the world to come.)
kural.kannan_exp: Envy is a damned ill that will destroy one’s wealth and consign him to a fiery inferno.

kural.pope_couplet: To men of envious heart, when comes increase of joy,Or loss to blameless men, the 'why' will thoughtful hearts employ
kural.pope_exp: The wealth of a man of envious mind and the poverty of the righteous will be pondered
kural.kannan_exp: The wealth in the hands of a person with envy at heart, and the destitution of a person, devoid of it, are aberrations that need to be analysed.

kural.pope_couplet: No envious men to large and full felicity attain;No men from envy free have failed a sure increase to gain
kural.pope_exp: Never have the envious become great; never have those who are free from envy been without greatness
kural.kannan_exp: An envious person doesn’t ever attain glory; of those who have no envy, there is none who has fallen from glory.

kural.pope_couplet: With soul unjust to covet others' well-earned store,Brings ruin to the home, to evil opes the door
kural.pope_exp: If a man departing from equity covet the property (of others), at that very time will his family be destroyed and guilt be incurred
kural.kannan_exp: If, without fairness, you desire to usurp the well-earned wealth of others, it will destroy your family, trigger more crimes and result in guilt.

kural.pope_couplet: Through lust of gain, no deeds that retribution bring,Do they, who shrink with shame from every unjust thing
kural.pope_exp: Those who blush at the want of equity will not commit disgraceful acts through desire of the profit that may be gained
kural.kannan_exp: Those, who desist being unfair, will not sin, coveting the material benefits of other’s possessions.

kural.pope_couplet: No deeds of ill, misled by base desire,Do they, whose souls to other joys aspire
kural.pope_exp: Those who desire the higher pleasures (of heaven) will not act unjustly through desire of the trifling joy. (in this life.)
kural.kannan_exp: Craving for the cheap thrills that other’s money can give, one, who seeks TRUE happiness, will not do an unrighteous act.

kural.pope_couplet: Men who have conquered sense, with sight from sordid vision freed,Desire not other's goods, e'en in the hour of sorest need
kural.pope_exp: The wise who have conquered their senses and are free from crime, will not covet (the things of others), with the thought "we are destitute."
kural.kannan_exp: One who is flawless and wise and has mastered all senses, will never feel ‘I’m poor’ and yearn for other’s wealth.

kural.pope_couplet: What gain, though lore refined of amplest reach he learn,His acts towards all mankind if covetous desire to folly turn
kural.pope_exp: What is the advantage of extensive and accurate knowledge if a man through covetousness act senselessly towards all ?
kural.kannan_exp: What is the use of deep wisdom and broad knowledge, if one acts indiscreetly with anyone, coveting his wealth.

kural.pope_couplet: Though, grace desiring, he in virtue's way stand strong,He's lost who wealth desires, and ponders deeds of wrong
kural.pope_exp: If he, who through desire of the virtue of kindness abides in the domestic state ie, the path in which it may be obtained, covet (the property of others) and think of evil methods (to obtain it), he will perish
kural.kannan_exp: One who seeks to be compassionate and manifests it in virtuous ways, will succumb to destructive thoughts and acts, if he falters and covets others’ possession.

kural.pope_couplet: Seek not increase by greed of gain acquired;That fruit matured yields never good desired
kural.pope_exp: Desire not the gain of covetousness In the enjoyment of its fruits there is no glory
kural.kannan_exp: Do not covet others’ wealth; on fruition, the consequences are always contemptible.

kural.pope_couplet: What saves prosperity from swift decline?Absence of lust to make another's cherished riches thine
kural.pope_exp: If it is weighed, "what is the indestructibility of wealth," it is freedom from covetousness
kural.kannan_exp: How will one’s wealth never shrink? By, not desiring to usurp the wealth of others.

kural.pope_couplet: Good fortune draws anigh in helpful time of need,To him who, schooled in virtue, guards his soul from greed
kural.pope_exp: Lakshmi, knowing the manner (in which she may approach) will immediately come to those wise men who, knowing that it is virtue, covet not the property of others
kural.kannan_exp: Wealth will find means to bestow itself on those who, knowing the virtue of not coveting others’ property, wisely desist from it.

kural.pope_couplet: From thoughtless lust of other's goods springs fatal ill,Greatness of soul that covets not shall triumph still
kural.pope_exp: To covet (the wealth of another) regardless of consequences will bring destruction That greatness (of mind) which covets not will give victory
kural.kannan_exp: Coveting others’ wealth injudiciously will result in dire consequences; one who takes pride in not so desiring will meet success.

kural.pope_couplet: Though virtuous words his lips speak not, and all his deeds are illIf neighbour he defame not, there's good within him still
kural.pope_exp: Though one do not even speak of virtue and live in sin, it will be well if it be said of him "he does not backbite."
kural.kannan_exp: Even someone, who is a sinner and does not speak of virtue, will benefit from never slandering anyone in his absence.

kural.pope_couplet: Than he who virtue scorns, and evil deeds performs, more vile,Is he that slanders friend, then meets him with false smile
kural.pope_exp: To smile deceitfully (in another's presence) after having reviled him to his destruction (behind his back) is a greater evil than the commission of (every other) sin and the destruction of (every) virtue
kural.kannan_exp: To wear a deceitful smile in one’s presence but to slander him in his absence slaughtering his reputation, is more harmful than refuting all that is virtuous and doing unrighteous deeds.

kural.pope_couplet: 'Tis greater gain of virtuous good for man to die,Than live to slander absent friend, and falsely praise when nigh
kural.pope_exp: Death rather than life will confer upon the deceitful backbiter the profit which (the treatises on) virtue point out
kural.kannan_exp: It is better to die than to live by backbiting and then being hypocritical; so dying, may yield the benefits spoken of by moral scriptures.

kural.pope_couplet: In presence though unkindly words you speak, say notIn absence words whose ill result exceeds your thought
kural.pope_exp: Though you speak without kindness before another's face speak not in his absence words which regard not the evil subsequently resulting from it
kural.kannan_exp: It is passable to speak impolitely to someone face to face, but never utter an imprudent word behind the back.

kural.pope_couplet: The slanderous meanness that an absent friend defames,'This man in words owns virtue, not in heart,' proclaims
kural.pope_exp: The emptiness of that man's mind who (merely) praises virtue will be seen from the meanness of reviling another behind his back
kural.kannan_exp: One, who extols righteousness but is insincere at heart, is exposed when he is devious enough to backbite.

kural.pope_couplet: Who on his neighbours' sins delights to dwell,The story of his sins, culled out with care, the world will tell
kural.pope_exp: The character of the faults of that man who publishes abroad the faults of others will be sought out and published
kural.kannan_exp: One who smears another behind his back, opens himself up to similar smear when he falters.

kural.pope_couplet: With friendly art who know not pleasant words to say,Speak words that sever hearts, and drive choice friends away
kural.pope_exp: Those who know not to live in friendship with amusing conversation will by back-biting estrange even their relatives
kural.kannan_exp: Through slander behind the back, one who gets estranged from friends, is incapable of indulging in pleasant talk and gaining friends.

kural.pope_couplet: Whose nature bids them faults of closest friends proclaimWhat mercy will they show to other men's good name
kural.pope_exp: What will those not do to strangers whose nature leads them to publish abroad the faults of their intimate friends ?
kural.kannan_exp: If one is known to habitually sully his friends for their faults, what damage would he do unto others?

kural.pope_couplet: 'Tis charity, I ween, that makes the earth sustain their loadWho, neighbours' absence watching, tales or slander tell abroad
kural.pope_exp: The world through charity supports the weight of those who reproach others observing their absence
kural.kannan_exp: Out of its commitment to its virtue of patience, the earth tolerates the presence of a slanderer on it.

kural.pope_couplet: If each his own, as neighbours' faults would scan,Could any evil hap to living man
kural.pope_exp: If they observed their own faults as they observe the faults of others, would any evil happen to men ?
kural.kannan_exp: If one looks at his faults in the same light as others’ faults, will any harm befell the lingering human lives?

kural.pope_couplet: Words without sense, while chafe the wise,Who babbles, him will all despise
kural.pope_exp: He who to the disgust of many speaks useless things will be despised by all
kural.kannan_exp: Those who make vain discourses, detested by many wise, will be disparaged by all.

kural.pope_couplet: Words without sense, where many wise men hear, to pourThan deeds to friends ungracious done offendeth more
kural.pope_exp: To speak useless things in the presence of many is a greater evil than to do unkind things towards friends
kural.kannan_exp: It is more harmful to speak vain words in front of many, than to do contemptible deeds to your friends.

kural.pope_couplet: Diffusive speech of useless words proclaimsA man who never righteous wisdom gains
kural.pope_exp: That conversation in which a man utters forth useless things will say of him "he is without virtue."
kural.kannan_exp: One’s gracelessness is exposed by his elaborate hollow speeches.

kural.pope_couplet: Unmeaning, worthless words, said to the multitude,To none delight afford, and sever men from good
kural.pope_exp: The words devoid of profit or pleasure which a man speaks will, being inconsistent with virtue,
kural.kannan_exp: Vain words spoken without dignity to a group, are ungainly, unrighteous and yield no gains.

kural.pope_couplet: Gone are both fame and boasted excellence,When men of worth speak of words devoid of sense
kural.pope_exp: If the good speak vain words their eminence and excellence will leave them
kural.kannan_exp: Reputation and respect will be lost, when an affable person speaks worthless words.

kural.pope_couplet: Who makes display of idle words' inanity,Call him not man, -chaff of humanity
kural.pope_exp: Call not him a man who parades forth his empty words Call him the chaff of men
kural.kannan_exp: Call him not a man, one who speaks vain words; he is a scum.

kural.pope_couplet: Let those who list speak things that no delight afford,'Tis good for men of worth to speak no idle word
kural.pope_exp: Let the wise if they will, speak things without excellence; it will be well for them not to speak useless things
kural.kannan_exp: A noble scholar may speak ungraciously, if he has to; but he must refrain from speaking vain words.

kural.pope_couplet: The wise who weigh the worth of every utterance,Speak none but words of deep significance
kural.pope_exp: The wise who seek after rare pleasures will not speak words that have not much weight in them
kural.kannan_exp: The wise, who seek to understand deeper significance of things, will not utter words with no substantial worth.

kural.pope_couplet: The men of vision pure, from wildering folly free,Not e'en in thoughtless hour, speak words of vanity
kural.pope_exp: Those wise men who are without faults and are freed from ignorance will not even forgetfully speak things that profit not
kural.kannan_exp: Those who are flawlessly wise, and have overcome all delusion, will desist from speaking worthless words, even unconsciously.

kural.pope_couplet: If speak you will, speak words that fruit afford,If speak you will, speak never fruitless word
kural.pope_exp: Speak what is useful, and speak not useless words
kural.kannan_exp: Speak, such that what you speak is worthy; speak not if what you speak is not worthy.

kural.pope_couplet: With sinful act men cease to feel the dread of ill within,The excellent will dread the wanton pride of cherished sin
kural.pope_exp: Those who have experience of evil deeds will not fear, but the excellent will fear the pride of sin
kural.kannan_exp: Sinners do not dread, while great men dread the delusion of evil deeds.

kural.pope_couplet: Since evils new from evils ever grow,Evil than fire works out more dreaded woe
kural.pope_exp: Because evil produces evil, therefore should evil be feared more than fire
kural.kannan_exp: Vile deeds yield vile results; and hence, vile deeds are more fearsome than fire.

kural.pope_couplet: Even to those that hate make no return of ill;So shalt thou wisdom's highest law, 'tis said, fulfil
kural.pope_exp: So shalt thou wisdom's highest law, 'tis said, fulfil
kural.kannan_exp: The foremost among all wise deeds, is to refrain from doing harmful deeds even to those who detest you.

kural.pope_couplet: Though good thy soul forget, plot not thy neighbour's fall,Thy plans shall 'virtue's Power' by ruin to thyself forestall
kural.pope_exp: Even though forgetfulness meditate not the ruin of another Virtue will meditate the ruin of him who thus meditates
kural.kannan_exp: Desire not the destruction of another, even sub-consciously; else, virtue will determine the destruction of the one who desires so.

kural.pope_couplet: Make not thy poverty a plea for ill;Thy evil deeds will make thee poorer still
kural.pope_exp: Commit not evil, saying, "I am poor": if you do, you will become poorer still
kural.kannan_exp: Don’t commit anything evil in the name of poverty; the poorer, it will render you.

kural.pope_couplet: What ranks as evil spare to do, if thou would'st shunAffliction sore through ill to thee by others done
kural.pope_exp: Let him not do evil to others who desires not that sorrows should pursue him
kural.kannan_exp: If one wishes not to be tormented by painful reactions, do not harm others.

kural.pope_couplet: From every enmity incurred there is to 'scape, a way;The wrath of evil deeds will dog men's steps, and slay
kural.pope_exp: However great be the enmity men have incurred they may still live The enmity of sin will incessantly pursue and kill
kural.kannan_exp: There is scope for surviving any sort of enmity; but there can be no respite from the repercussions of an evil deed.

kural.pope_couplet: Man's shadow dogs his steps where'er he wends;Destruction thus on sinful deeds attends
kural.pope_exp: Destruction will dwell at the heels of those who commit evil even as their shadow that leaves them not
kural.kannan_exp: The shadow stays rooted to the foot; the evil that men do will remain to torment them.

kural.pope_couplet: Beware, if to thyself thyself is dear,Lest thou to aught that ranks as ill draw near
kural.pope_exp: If a man love himself, let him not commit any sin however small
kural.kannan_exp: If one loves himself, he shouldn’t do an evil act, howsoever small it is.

kural.pope_couplet: The man, to devious way of sin that never turned aside,From ruin rests secure, whatever ills betide
kural.pope_exp: Know ye that he is freed from destruction who commits no evil, going to neither side of the right path
kural.kannan_exp: Know a man to be free of torment, if he doesn’t take a shortcut to do an evil deed.

kural.pope_couplet: Duty demands no recompense; to clouds of heaven,By men on earth, what answering gift is given
kural.pope_exp: Benevolence seeks not a return. What does the world give back to the clouds ?
kural.kannan_exp: Doing one’s duty without desiring any favours, is like rain; what can the world do in return for the rains.

kural.pope_couplet: The worthy say, when wealth rewards their toil-spent hours,For uses of beneficence alone 'tis ours
kural.pope_exp: All the wealth acquired with perseverance by the worthy is for the exercise of benevolence
kural.kannan_exp: The purpose of one’s hard-earned money is to be deployed to help the deserving.

kural.pope_couplet: To 'due beneficence' no equal good we know,Amid the happy gods, or in this world below
kural.pope_exp: It is difficult to obtain another good equal to benevolence either in this world or in that of the gods
kural.kannan_exp: In this world and the other, it is tough to attain anything better than beneficence.
