kural.pope_couplet: Fools are they who their nakedness conceal,And yet their faults unveiled reveal
kural.pope_exp: Even to cover one's nakedness would be folly, if (one's) faults were not covered (by forsaking them)
kural.kannan_exp: It is simpleminded to cover one’s private parts when there is no way to mask their flaws.

kural.pope_couplet: From out his soul who lets the mystic teachings die,Entails upon himself abiding misery
kural.pope_exp: The fool who neglects precious counsel does, of his own accord, a great injury to himself
kural.kannan_exp: When a precious teaching is imparted to a simpleton, by not grasping it, they self-inflict immense harm.

kural.pope_couplet: Advised, he heeds not; of himself knows nothing wise;This man's whole life is all one plague until he dies
kural.pope_exp: The fool will not perform (his duties) even when advised nor ascertain them himself; such a soul is a
kural.kannan_exp: He neither obeys others nor reasons out himself – he is an ailment till he is alive.

kural.pope_couplet: That man is blind to eyes that will not see who knowledge shows;-The blind man still in his blind fashion knows
kural.pope_exp: One who would teach a fool will (simply) betray his folly; and the fool would (still) think himself "wise in his own conceit"
kural.kannan_exp: He who shows him who can’t see, himself can’t see; he who can’t see sees only what he sees.

kural.pope_couplet: Who what the world affirms as false proclaim,O'er all the earth receive a demon's name
kural.pope_exp: He who denies the existence of what the world believes in will be regarded as a demon on earth
kural.kannan_exp: What the (wise of the) world says exists, he denies; he shall be deemed a ghost in this world.

kural.pope_couplet: Hostility disunion's plague will bring,That evil quality, to every living thing
kural.pope_exp: The disease which fosters the evil of disunion among all creatures is termed hatred by the wise
kural.kannan_exp: The concomitant ills of the uncultured trait of being at divergence with all beings is termed as discord.

kural.pope_couplet: Though men disunion plan, and do thee much despite'Tis best no enmity to plan, nor evil deeds requite
kural.pope_exp: Though disagreeable things may be done from (a feeling of) disunion, it is far better that nothing painful be done from (that of) hatred
kural.kannan_exp: On account of differences, if one offends us, it is important to disregard the discord and do no harm.

kural.pope_couplet: If enmity, that grievous plague, you shun,Endless undying praises shall be won
kural.pope_exp: To rid one-self of the distressing dtsease of hatred will bestow (on one) a never-decreasing imperishable fame
kural.kannan_exp: If the distressing disease of discord is discarded, it yields flawless fame that never fades.

kural.pope_couplet: Joy of joys abundant grows,When malice dies that woe of woes
kural.pope_exp: If hatred which is the greatest misery is destroyed, it will yield the greatest delight
kural.kannan_exp: Discord is the misery of all miseries; when it goes the joy of all joys ensues.

kural.pope_couplet: If men from enmity can keep their spirits free,Who over them shall gain the victory
kural.pope_exp: Who indeed would think of conquering those who naturally shrink back from hatred ?
kural.kannan_exp: Those who can act against their discords – who has the capacity to consider overcoming them?

kural.pope_couplet: The life of those who cherished enmity hold dear,To grievous fault and utter death is near
kural.pope_exp: Failure and ruin are not far from him who says it is sweet to excel in hatred
kural.kannan_exp: The life of one who relishes a spate of discords has in its proximity suffering and demise.

kural.pope_couplet: The very truth that greatness gives their eyes can never see,Who only know to work men woe, fulfilled of enmity
kural.pope_exp: Who only know to work men woe, fulfilled of enmity
kural.kannan_exp: They shall never see the transcendent truth, those devious minds teeming with discord.

kural.pope_couplet: 'Tis gain to turn the soul from enmity;Ruin reigns where this hath mastery
kural.pope_exp: Shrinking back from hatred will yield wealth; indulging in its increase will hasten ruin
kural.kannan_exp: Siding against one’s own discord is valuable; allowing it to accumulate invites injury.

kural.pope_couplet: Men think not hostile thought in fortune's favouring hour,They cherish enmity when in misfortune's power
kural.pope_exp: At the approach of wealth one will not think of hatred (but) to secure one's ruin, one will look to its increase
kural.kannan_exp: When there is benefit, the discord goes unnoticed. When it is detrimental, it seems stark.

kural.pope_couplet: From enmity do all afflictive evils flow;But friendliness doth wealth of kindly good bestow
kural.pope_exp: All calamities are caused by hatred; but by the delight (of friendship) is caused the great wealth of good virtues
kural.kannan_exp: All woes emanate from discord. The great wealth – good deeds and joy for all, stems from friendly smiles.

kural.pope_couplet: With stronger than thyself, turn from the strife away;With weaker shun not, rather court the fray
kural.pope_exp: Avoid offering resistance to the strong; (but) never fail to cherish enmity towards the weak
kural.kannan_exp: Avoid hostility with the strong; unleash your enmity on the weak failing to do so.

kural.pope_couplet: No kinsman's love, no strength of friends has he;How can he bear his foeman's enmity
kural.pope_exp: How can he who is unloving, destitute of powerful aids, and himself without strength overcome the might of his foe ?
kural.kannan_exp: Loveless, lacks right companions, and on his own has no strengths – how shall the might of his foes fail?

kural.pope_couplet: A craven thing! knows nought, accords with none, gives nought away;To wrath of any foe he falls an easy prey
kural.pope_exp: In the estimation of foes miserably weak is he, who is timid, ignorant, unsociable and niggardly
kural.kannan_exp: Timid, ignorant, unsettled and ungenerous – he is easy prey to his foes.

kural.pope_couplet: His wrath still blazes, every secret told; each dayThis man's in every place to every foe an easy prey
kural.pope_exp: He who neither refrains from anger nor keeps his secrets will at all times and in all places be easily conquered by all
kural.kannan_exp: Never ceases to be angry, ever insatiate – anytime, anywhere, he is easy prey for anyone.

kural.pope_couplet: No way of right he scans, no precepts bind, no crimes affright,No grace of good he owns; such man's his foes' delight
kural.pope_exp: (A) pleasing (object) to his foes is he who reads not moral works, does nothing that is enjoined by them cares not for reproach and is not possessed of good qualities
kural.kannan_exp: Doesn’t look up the right means, seizes not his opportunities, fears no ignominy, and lacks character – his foes relish him.

kural.pope_couplet: Blind in his rage, his lustful passions rage and swell;If such a man mislikes you, like it well
kural.pope_exp: Highly to be desired is the hatred of him whose anger is blind, and whose lust increases beyond measure
kural.kannan_exp: Has unheard of and unseeing anger, and is prodigiously lustful – enmity with him will be seized with glee.

kural.pope_couplet: Unseemly are his deeds, yet proffering aid, the man draws nigh:His hate- 'tis cheap at any price- be sure to buy
kural.pope_exp: It is indeed necessary to obtain even by purchase the hatred of him who having begun (a work) does what is not conductive (to its accomplishment)
kural.kannan_exp: He is adept at harming his own endeavours – give anything to gain his enmity.

kural.pope_couplet: No gracious gifts he owns, faults many cloud his fame;His foes rejoice, for none with kindred claim
kural.pope_exp: He will become friendless who is without (any good) qualities and whose faults are many; (such a character) is a help to (his) foes
kural.kannan_exp: Shorn of good qualities, filled with flaws, free of allies – he is the best safeguard for his foes.

kural.pope_couplet: The joy of victory is never far removed from thoseWho've luck to meet with ignorant and timid foes
kural.pope_exp: There will be no end of lofty delights to the victorious, if their foes are (both) ignorant and timid
kural.kannan_exp: Rapturous joy never ends for aggressors who gain as foes, the foolish and fearful .

kural.pope_couplet: The task of angry war with men unlearned in virtue's loreWho will not meet, glory shall meet him never more
kural.pope_exp: The light (of fame) will never be gained by him who gains not the trifling reputation of having fought an unlearned (foe)
kural.kannan_exp: Ignorant, irritable and disinclined to earn a trifle – fame never favours him.

kural.pope_couplet: For Hate, that ill-conditioned thing not e'en in jestLet any evil longing rule your breast
kural.pope_exp: The evil of hatred is not of a nature to be desired by one even in sport
kural.kannan_exp: Enmity is an oddity that is best left undesired even in jest.

kural.pope_couplet: Although you hate incur of those whose ploughs are bows,Make not the men whose ploughs are words your foes
kural.pope_exp: Though you may incur the hatred of warriors whose ploughs are bows, incur not that of ministers whose ploughs are words
kural.kannan_exp: You may gain the enmity of the ploughman wielding a bow as plough but not that of the one wielding the word.

kural.pope_couplet: Than men of mind diseased, a wretch more utterly forlorn,Is he who stands alone, object of many foeman's scorn
kural.pope_exp: He who being alone, incurs the hatred of many is more infatuated than even mad men
kural.kannan_exp: One who, alone, antagonizes many, has a dimmer wit than a loony.

kural.pope_couplet: The world secure on his dexterity depends,Whose worthy rule can change his foes to friends
kural.pope_exp: Whose worthy rule can change his foes to friends
kural.kannan_exp: The one with the virtue of turning a foe into a friend – the world shall rest under the sway of his virtuosity.

kural.pope_couplet: Without ally, who fights with twofold enemy o'ermatched,Must render one of these a friend attached
kural.pope_exp: He who is alone and helpless while his foes are two should secure one of them as an agreeable help (to himself)
kural.kannan_exp: If one has no allies but two foes, better befriend one of them.

kural.pope_couplet: Whether you trust or not, in time of sore distress,Questions of diff'rence or agreement cease to press
kural.pope_exp: Though (one's foe is) aware or not of one's misfortune one should act so as neither to join nor separate (from him)
kural.kannan_exp: Whether you’ve qualified someone as a foe or not, in troubled times, it is better not to get cozy nor split.

kural.pope_couplet: To those who know them not, complain not of your woes;Nor to your foeman's eyes infirmities disclose
kural.pope_exp: Relate not your suffering even to friends who are ignorant of it, nor refer to your weakness in the presence of your foes
kural.kannan_exp: Express not your pain to those who can’t empathize; expose not your frailties to your foes.

kural.pope_couplet: Know thou the way, then do thy part, thyself defend;Thus shall the pride of those that hate thee have an end
kural.pope_exp: The joy of one's foes will be destroyed if one guards oneself by knowing the way (of acting) and securing assistance
kural.kannan_exp: Knowing oneself and one’s foes, preparing oneself and strengthening the defences – these surely shall quell the vanity of the enemy.

kural.pope_couplet: Destroy the thorn, while tender point can work thee no offence;Matured by time, 'twill pierce the hand that plucks it thence
kural.pope_exp: A thorny tree should be felled while young, (for) when it is grown it will destroy the hand of the feller
kural.kannan_exp: Weed out a thorn tree when it is still slender; once fully grown, it’ll slash the hands of the weeder.

kural.pope_couplet: But breathe upon them, and they surely die,Who fail to tame the pride of angry enemy
kural.pope_exp: Those who do not destroy the pride of those who hate (them) will certainly not exist even to breathe
kural.kannan_exp: One who can’t crush the conceit of the enemy, will be vanquished the moment they hiss.

kural.pope_couplet: Water and shade, if they unwholesome prove, will bring you painAnd qualities of friends who treacherous act, will be your bane
kural.pope_exp: Shade and water are not pleasant, (if) they cause disease; so are the qualities of (one's) relations not agreeable, (if) they cause pain
kural.kannan_exp: Even shade and water, when noxious, can be baneful; kith and kin, when malicious, can be harmful.

kural.pope_couplet: Dread not the foes that as drawn swords appear;Friendship of foes, who seem like kinsmen, fear
kural.pope_exp: Fear not foes (who say they would cut) like a sword; (but) fear the friendship of foes (who seemingly
kural.kannan_exp: Fear not foes, overt like swords; but those faking as friends – fear the ties with them.

kural.pope_couplet: Of hidden hate beware, and guard thy life;In troublous time 'twill deeper wound than potter's knife
kural.pope_exp: Fear internal enmity and guard yourself; (if not) it will destroy (you) in an evil hour, as surely as the tool which cuts the potter's clay
kural.kannan_exp: Fear internal strife and protect yourself; during trouble, like a tool that cuts wet clay, it will hurt without fail.

kural.pope_couplet: If secret enmities arise that minds pervert,Then even kin unkind will work thee grievous hurt
kural.pope_exp: The secret enmity of a person whose mind in unreformed will lead to many evils causing disaffection among (one's) relations
kural.kannan_exp: When internal strife that disconcerts minds appears, it gives rise to flaws that unsettle the kith.

kural.pope_couplet: Amid one's relatives if hidden hath arise,'Twill hurt inflict in deadly wise
kural.pope_exp: If there appears internal hatred in a (king's) family; it will lead to many a fatal crime
kural.kannan_exp: If internal conflicts surface amongst the kin, many a destructive flaw is aroused.

kural.pope_couplet: If discord finds a place midst those who dwelt at one before,'Tis ever hard to keep destruction from the door
kural.pope_exp: If hatred arises among (one's) own people, it will be hardly possible (for one) to escape death
kural.kannan_exp: If disharmony crops up among those who are at one with each other, infallibility is impossible to achieve.

kural.pope_couplet: As casket with its cover, though in one they live alway,No union to the house where hate concealed hath sway
kural.pope_exp: Never indeed will a family subject to internal hatred unite (really) though it may present an apparent union like that of a casket and its lid
kural.kannan_exp: Though it appears well joint like a copper vessel, a house ridden with internal strifes shall never jell.

kural.pope_couplet: As gold with which the file contends is worn away,So strength of house declines where hate concealed hath sway
kural.pope_exp: A family subject to internal hatred will wear out and lose its strength like iron that has been filed away
kural.kannan_exp: Like a metal abraded by a file, the might of a clan is eroded by enemies within.

kural.pope_couplet: Though slight as shred of 'seasame' seed it be,Destruction lurks in hidden enmity
kural.pope_exp: Although internal hatred be as small as the fragment of the sesamum (seed), still does destruction dwell in it
kural.kannan_exp: It maybe tiny as a split sesame, but disaster resides in internal strife.

kural.pope_couplet: Domestic life with those who don't agree,Is dwelling in a shed with snake for company
kural.pope_exp: Living with those who do not agree (with one) is like dwelling with a cobra (in the same) hut
kural.kannan_exp: Life with those whose hearts are not in harmony is like staying in a hut with a snake for company.

kural.pope_couplet: The chiefest care of those who guard themselves from ill,Is not to slight the powers of those who work their mighty will
kural.pope_exp: Not to disregard the power of those who can carry out (their wishes) is more important than all the watchfulness of those who guard (themselves against evil)
kural.kannan_exp: For those keen on self-preservation, the prominent concern is not to belittle the capabilities of the capable.

kural.pope_couplet: If men will lead their lives reckless of great men's will,Such life, through great men's powers, will bring perpetual ill
kural.pope_exp: To behave without respect for the great (rulers) will make them do (us) irremediable evils
kural.kannan_exp: If we rankle those worthy of veneration, they can cause unceasing tribulation.

kural.pope_couplet: Who ruin covet let them shut their ears, and do despiteTo those who, where they list to ruin have the might
kural.pope_exp: If a person desires ruin, let him not listen to the righteous dictates of law, but commit crimes against those who are able to slay (other sovereigns)
kural.kannan_exp: If you are keen on self destruction, act with disregard and denigrate those who can destroy at will.

kural.pope_couplet: When powerless man 'gainst men of power will evil deeds essay,Tis beck'ning with the hand for Death to seize them for its prey
kural.pope_exp: The weak doing evil to the strong is like beckoning Yama to come (and destroy them)
kural.kannan_exp: The incapable venturing to harm the capable, is like waving a welcome to the deity of death.

kural.pope_couplet: Who dare the fiery wrath of monarchs dread,Where'er they flee, are numbered with the dead
kural.pope_exp: Those who have incurred the wrath of a cruel and mighty potentate will not prosper wherever they may go
kural.kannan_exp: Wherever one flees, and forever, there can be no respite, after enraging a ruler with fiery might.

kural.pope_couplet: Though in the conflagration caught, he may escape from thence:He 'scapes not who in life to great ones gives offence
kural.pope_exp: Though burnt by a fire (from a forest), one may perhaps live; (but) never will he live who has shown disrespect to the great (devotees)
kural.kannan_exp: One may survive being fried in a fire but not after offending the venerable.

kural.pope_couplet: Though every royal gift, and stores of wealth your life should crown,What are they, if the worthy men of mighty virtue frown
kural.pope_exp: If a king incurs the wrath of the righteous great, what will become of his government with its splendid auxiliaries and (all) its untold wealth ?
kural.kannan_exp: Of what use are a life good in all aspects, and immense wealth, if one infuriates men of outstanding greatness and prowess.

kural.pope_couplet: If they, whose virtues like a mountain rise, are light esteemed;They die from earth who, with their households, ever-during seemed
kural.pope_exp: If (the) hill-like (devotees) resolve on destruction, those who seemed to be everlasting will be destroyed root and branch from the earth
kural.kannan_exp: They, who seem tenacious, with their clans shall perish from this world, if august men, great as a mountain, are slighted.

kural.pope_couplet: When blazes forth the wrath of men of lofty fame,Kings even fall from high estate and perish in the flame
kural.pope_exp: Kings even fall from high estate and perish in the flame
kural.kannan_exp: An emperor, one may be, but he shall be derailed and his reign wrecked, if persons with lofty ideals are incensed.

kural.pope_couplet: Though all-surpassing wealth of aid the boast,If men in glorious virtue great are wrath, they're lost
kural.pope_exp: Though in possession of numerous auxiliaries, they will perish who are-exposed to the wrath of the noble whose penance is boundless
kural.kannan_exp: One may have the best of allies but cannot survive the wrath of those with the best of qualities.

kural.pope_couplet: Who give their soul to love of wife acquire not nobler gain;Who give their soul to strenuous deeds such meaner joys disdain
kural.pope_exp: Those who lust after their wives will not attain the excellence of virtue; and it is just this that is not desired by those who are bent on acquiring wealth
kural.kannan_exp: One who forever acts out of fervor for his wife never attains anything worthy; this is the trait that those who focus on execution shun.

kural.pope_couplet: Who gives himself to love of wife, careless of noble nameHis wealth will clothe him with o'erwhelming shame
kural.pope_exp: The wealth of him who, regardless (of his manliness), devotes himself to his wife's feminine nature will cause great shame (to ali men) and to himself;
kural.kannan_exp: Without preserving the good, driven by the desire for the woman- the wealth made thus is a greatly disconcerting disgrace.

kural.pope_couplet: Who to his wife submits, his strange, unmanly moodWill daily bring him shame among the good
kural.pope_exp: The frailty that stoops to a wife will always make (her husband) feel ashamed among the good
kural.kannan_exp: Stooping to go against the grain by submitting to the wife’s will, always embarrasses good men.

kural.pope_couplet: No glory crowns e'en manly actions wroughtBy him who dreads his wife, nor gives the other world a thought
kural.pope_exp: The undertaking of one, who fears his wife and is therefore destitute of (bliss), will never be applauded
kural.kannan_exp: There is no salvation for one who fears his wife; never can he achieve fame nor mastery over execution.

kural.pope_couplet: Who quakes before his wife will ever tremble too,Good deeds to men of good deserts to do
kural.pope_exp: He that fears his wife will always be afraid of doing good deeds (even) to the good
kural.kannan_exp: One who fears his wife will forever fear doing good to the good folk.

kural.pope_couplet: Though, like the demi-gods, in bliss they dwell secure from harm,Those have no dignity who fear the housewife's slender arm
kural.pope_exp: They that fear the bamboo-like shoulders of their wives will be destitute of manliness though they may flourish like the Gods
kural.kannan_exp: One may live amongst the celestial beings but has no standing, if he fears the drooping of the shapely shoulders of his wife.

kural.pope_couplet: The dignity of modest womanhood excelsHis manliness, obedient to a woman's law who dwells
kural.pope_exp: Even shame faced womanhood is more to be esteemed than the shameless manhood that performs
kural.kannan_exp: The demure woman deserves more acclaim than the manliness that dances to the woman’s tune.

kural.pope_couplet: Who to the will of her with beauteous brow their lives conform,Aid not their friends in need, nor acts of charity perform
kural.pope_exp: Those who yield to the wishes of their wives will neither relieve the wants of (their) friends nor perform virtuous deeds
kural.kannan_exp: One who caters to the whims of her, with elegant brows, shall never do any good nor resolve any of his friends’ woes.

kural.pope_couplet: No virtuous deed, no seemly wealth, no pleasure, restsWith them who live obedient to their wives' behests
kural.pope_exp: From those who obey the commands of their wives are to be expected neither deeds of virtue, nor those of wealth nor (even) those of pleasure
kural.kannan_exp: Virtuous deeds, valuable possession and various pursuits are beyond those who do what the wife bids.

kural.pope_couplet: Where pleasures of the mind, that dwell in realms of thought, abound,Folly, that springs from overweening woman's love, is never found
kural.pope_exp: The foolishness that results from devotion to a wife will never be found in those who possess a reflecting mind and a prosperity (flowing) therefrom
kural.kannan_exp: Cultured hearts with precious thoughts allow not the folly of appeasing their consorts.

kural.pope_couplet: Those that choice armlets wear who seek not thee with love,But seek thy wealth, their pleasant words will ruin prove
kural.pope_exp: The sweet words of elegant braceleted (prostitutes) who desire (a man) not from affection but from avarice, will cause sorrow
kural.kannan_exp: Bedecked with bracelets, she seeks him not for love but money – her saccharine words are charged with disgrace.

kural.pope_couplet: Who weigh the gain, and utter virtuous words with vicious heart,Weighing such women's worth, from their society depart
kural.pope_exp: One must ascertain the character of the ill-natured women who after ascertaining the wealth (of a man) speak (as if they were) good natured-ones, and avoid intercourse (with them)
kural.kannan_exp: Discern and spurn pretentious women who schemingly gloat.

kural.pope_couplet: As one in darkened room, some stranger corpse inarms,Is he who seeks delight in mercenary women's charms
kural.pope_exp: The false embraces of wealth-loving women are like (hired men) embracing a strange corpse in a dark room
kural.kannan_exp: The fake cuddling of women coveting money is like hugging an unknown corpse in a dark room.

kural.pope_couplet: Their worthless charms, whose only weal is wealth of gain,From touch of these the wise, who seek the wealth of grace, abstain
kural.pope_exp: The wise who seek the wealth of grace will not desire the base favours of those who regard wealth (and not pleasure) as (their) riches
kural.kannan_exp: The wise who seek the way of compassion are not swayed by trivial pleasures of covetous women.

kural.pope_couplet: From contact with their worthless charms, whose charms to all are free,The men with sense of good and lofty wisdom blest will flee;
kural.pope_exp: Those whose knowledge is made excellent by their (natural) sense will not covet the trffling delights
kural.kannan_exp: Wise men renowned for their sagacity shun the trite frolics of women who profess love for all.

kural.pope_couplet: From touch of those who worthless charms, with wanton arts, display,The men who would their own true good maintain will turn away
kural.pope_exp: Those who would spread (the fame of) their own goodness will not desire the shoulders of those,who rejoice in their accomplishments and bestow their despicable favours (on all who pay)
kural.kannan_exp: Those who care for themselves care not for the shoulders of those who offer exaggerated banal joys.

kural.pope_couplet: Who cherish alien thoughts while folding in their feigned embrace,These none approach save those devoid of virtue's grace
kural.pope_exp: Those who are destitute of a perfectly (reformed) mind will covet the shoulders of those who embrace (them) while their hearts covet other things
kural.kannan_exp: Those with discontented hearts embrace the shoulders of those who make love with devious thoughts in their hearts.

kural.pope_couplet: As demoness who lures to ruin woman's treacherous loveTo men devoid of wisdom's searching power will prove
kural.pope_exp: The wise say that to such as are destitute of discerning sense the embraces of faithless women are (as ruinous as those of) the celestail female
kural.kannan_exp: Those who cannot reason wisely see a divine enchantress in a dubious woman’s embrace.

kural.pope_couplet: The wanton's tender arm, with gleaming jewels decked,Is hell, where sink degraded souls of men abject
kural.pope_exp: The delicate shoulders of prostitutes with excellent jewels are a hell into which are plunged the ignorant base
kural.kannan_exp: Soft shoulders of loose women, decked with jewels, is the hell where imprudent louts dwell.

kural.pope_couplet: Women of double minds, strong drink, and dice; to these giv'n o'er,Are those on whom the light of Fortune shines no more
kural.pope_exp: Treacherous women, liquor, and gambling are the associates of such as have forsaken by Fortune
kural.kannan_exp: Deceitful women, drink and dice are friends of those wantonly dumping their wealth.

kural.pope_couplet: Who love the palm's intoxicating juice, each day,No rev'rence they command, their glory fades away
kural.pope_exp: Those who always thirst after drink will neither inspire fear (in others) nor retain the light (of their fame)
kural.kannan_exp: They shall not be respected nor feared, and they shall lose their glory – they who are in love with alcohol.

kural.pope_couplet: Drink not inebriating draught Let him count well the costWho drinks, by drinking, all good men's esteem is lost
kural.pope_exp: Let no liquor be drunk; if it is desired, let it be drunk by those who care not for esteem of the great
kural.kannan_exp: Consume not alcohol; consume if you will, those who care not to be held highly by the noble.

kural.pope_couplet: The drunkard's joy is sorrow to his mother's eyes;What must it be in presence of the truly wise
kural.pope_exp: Intoxication is painful even in the presence of (one's) mother; what will it not then be in that of the wise ?
kural.kannan_exp: Drunken revelry is horrid in front of your mother; how would it seem in front of the esteemed?

kural.pope_couplet: Shame, goodly maid, will turn her back for aye on themWho sin the drunkard's grievous sin, that all condemn
kural.pope_exp: The fair maid of modesty will turn her back on those who are guilty of the great and abominable crime of drunkenness
kural.kannan_exp: The good lady, Sense of Shame, will turn her back on those despicably guilty of being drunk.

kural.pope_couplet: With gift of goods who self-oblivion buys,Is ignorant of all that man should prize
kural.pope_exp: To give money and purchase unconsciousness is the result of one's ignorance of (one's own actions)
kural.kannan_exp: They have no sense of consequences, those who pay to lose their senses.

kural.pope_couplet: Sleepers are as the dead, no otherwise they seem;Who drink intoxicating draughts, they poison quaff, we deem
kural.pope_exp: They that sleep resemble the deed; (likewise) they that drink are no other than poison-eaters
kural.kannan_exp: One who is asleep is no different from the dead; one who consumes alcohol forever consumes poison.

kural.pope_couplet: Who turn aside to drink, and droop their heavy eye,Shall be their townsmen's jest, when they the fault espy
kural.pope_exp: Those who always intoxicate themselves by a private (indulgence in) drink; will have their secrets detected and laughed at by their fellow-townsmen
kural.kannan_exp: Those who are in a perpetual drunken stupor shall be sneered at by the knowing locals.

kural.pope_couplet: No more in secret drink, and then deny thy hidden fraud;What in thy mind lies hid shall soon be known abroad
kural.pope_exp: Let (the drunkard) give up saying "I have never drunk"; (for) the moment (he drinks) he will simply betray his former attempt to conceal
kural.kannan_exp: Drop the pretense of never feeling merry while drinking; all that’s hidden in your heart will tumble out.

kural.pope_couplet: Like him who, lamp in hand, would seek one sunk beneath the waveIs he who strives to sober drunken man with reasonings grave
kural.pope_exp: Reasoning with a drunkard is like going under water with a torch in search of a drowned man
kural.kannan_exp: Making an inebriated person see reason is like pursuing with a flame, someone under water .

kural.pope_couplet: When one, in sober interval, a drunken man espies,Does he not think, 'Such is my folly in my revelries'
kural.pope_exp: When (a drunkard) who is sober sees one who is not, it looks as if he remembered not the evil effects of his (own) drink
kural.kannan_exp: While sober, will he not think of his crapulence when he sees others sloshed under the influence?

kural.pope_couplet: Seek not the gamester's play; though you should win,Your gain is as the baited hook the fish takes in
kural.pope_exp: Though able to win, let not one desire gambling; (for) even what is won is like a fish swallowing the iron in fish-hook
kural.kannan_exp: Love not gambling even when you win. To win is akin to a fish biting the metallic hook on a fishing line.

kural.pope_couplet: Is there for gamblers, too, that gaining one a hundred lose, some wayThat they may good obtain, and see a prosperous day
kural.pope_exp: That they may good obtain, and see a prosperous day? Is there indeed a means of livelihood that can bestow happiness on gamblers who gain one and lose a hundred?
kural.kannan_exp: Can there ever be a rewarding course of life for a gambler who wins one to lose a hundred.

kural.pope_couplet: If prince unceasing speak of nought but play,Treasure and revenue will pass from him away
kural.pope_exp: If the king is incessantly addicted to the rolling dice in the hope of gain, his wealth and the resources thereof will take their departure and fall into other's hands
kural.kannan_exp: If one keeps calling as the dice roll, their wealth shall roll away to others.

kural.pope_couplet: Gaming brings many woes, and ruins fair renown;Nothing to want brings men so surely down
kural.pope_exp: There is nothing else that brings (us) poverty like gambling which causes many a misery and destroys (one's) reputation
kural.kannan_exp: Nothing else can cause as much poverty as the degrading and demeaning gambling.

kural.pope_couplet: The dice, and gaming-hall, and gamester's art, they eager sought,Thirsting for gain- the men in other days who came to nought
kural.pope_exp: Penniless are those who by reason of their attachment would never forsake gambling, the gamblingplace and the handling (of dice)
kural.kannan_exp: The dice, the casino and the playing hand – those who lovingly embrace these lose everything.

kural.pope_couplet: Gambling's Misfortune's other name: o'er whom she casts her veil,They suffer grievous want, and sorrows sore bewail
kural.pope_exp: Those who are swallowed by the goddess called "gambling" will never have their hunger satisfied, but suffer the pangs of hell in the next world
kural.kannan_exp: When one is enclasped by Gambling, the Imp of Misfortune, they shall starve and suffer.

kural.pope_couplet: Ancestral wealth and noble fame to ruin haste,If men in gambler's halls their precious moments waste
kural.pope_exp: To waste time at the place of gambling will destroy inherited wealth and goodness of character
kural.kannan_exp: When one enters the gambling den at dawn, their character and inheritance decline.

kural.pope_couplet: Gambling wastes wealth, to falsehood bends the soul: it drives awayAll grace, and leaves the man to utter misery a prey
kural.pope_exp: Gambling destroys property, teaches falsehood, puts an end to benevolence, and brings in misery (here and hereafter)
kural.kannan_exp: It erodes wealth and imposes falsehood – gambling that causes torment and erases tenderness.

kural.pope_couplet: Clothes, wealth, food, praise, and learning, all departFrom him on gambler's gain who sets his heart
kural.pope_exp: The habit of gambling prevents the attainment of these five: clothing, wealth, food, fame and learning
kural.kannan_exp: Food, dress, learning, wealth and fame – these five elude one who takes to the dice.

kural.pope_couplet: Howe'er he lose, the gambler's heart is ever in the play;E'en so the soul, despite its griefs, would live on earth alway
kural.pope_exp: As the gambler loves (his vice) the more he loses by it, so does the soul love (the body) the more it suffers through it
kural.kannan_exp: Like the spirit that yet loves the body in torment, the gambler loves to wager despite the losses.

kural.pope_couplet: The learned books count three, with wind as first; of these,As any one prevail, or fail; 'twill cause disease
kural.pope_exp: If (food and work are either) excessive or deficient, the three things enumerated by (medical) writers, flatulence, biliousness, and phlegm, will cause (one) disease
kural.kannan_exp: Food and deed, both in excess and deficit, cause disease, induced by the three (humors)* listed by the learned, starting with wind.

kural.pope_couplet: No need of medicine to heal your body's pain,If, what you ate before digested well, you eat again
kural.pope_exp: No medicine is necessary for him who eats after assuring (himself) that what he has (already) eaten has been digested
kural.kannan_exp: The body needs no medicine, if one eats after ensuring the earlier intake is digested.

kural.pope_couplet: Who has a body gained may long the gift retain,If, food digested well, in measure due he eat again
kural.pope_exp: If (one's food has been) digested let one eat with moderation; (for) that is the way to prolong the life of an embodied soul
kural.kannan_exp: After digestion, eat in right measure. This is the way for the possessor of the body to prolong its being.

kural.pope_couplet: Knowing the food digested well, when hunger prompteth thee,With constant care, the viands choose that well agree
kural.pope_exp: (First) assure yourself that your food has been digested and never fail to eat, when very hungry, whatever is not disagreeable (to you)
kural.kannan_exp: After ascertaining digestion, when you feel quite hungry, eat, in right measure, food that suits your constitution.

kural.pope_couplet: With self-denial take the well-selected meal;So shall thy frame no sudden sickness feel
kural.pope_exp: There will be no disaster to one's life if one eats with moderation, food that is not disagreeable
kural.kannan_exp: If one eats after refusing incompatible food there is no harm for their existence.

kural.pope_couplet: On modest temperance as pleasures pure,So pain attends the greedy epicure
kural.pope_exp: As pleasure dwells with him who eats moderately, so disease (dwells) with the glutton who eats voraciously
kural.kannan_exp: Joy resides with one who knows what not and how much to eat. Likewise, disease rests with the glutton.

kural.pope_couplet: Who largely feeds, nor measure of the fire within maintains,That thoughtless man shall feel unmeasured pains
kural.pope_exp: He will be afflicted with numberless diseases, who eats immoderately, ignorant (of the rules of health)
kural.kannan_exp: One who cannot judge his extent of hunger and gobbles up greedily will be afflicted with boundless malady.

kural.pope_couplet: Disease, its cause, what may abate the ill:Let leech examine these, then use his skill
kural.pope_exp: Let the physician enquire into the (nature of the) disease, its cause and its method of cure and treat it faithfully according to (medical rule)
kural.kannan_exp: Diagnose the disease, detect its root cause, discern its cure and then act aptly.

kural.pope_couplet: The habitudes of patient and disease, the crises of the illThese must the learned leech think over well, then use his skill
kural.pope_exp: The learned (physician) should ascertain the condition of his patient; the nature of his disease, and the season (of the year) and (then) proceed (with his treatment)
kural.kannan_exp: The learned medic should consider the state of the ailing, the extent of ailment and the timing, and then treat.

kural.pope_couplet: For patient, leech, and remedies, and him who waits by patient's side,The art of medicine must fourfold code of laws provide
kural.pope_exp: Medical science consists of four parts, viz, patient, physician, medicine and compounder; and each of these (again) contains four sub-divisions
kural.kannan_exp: The ailing, the medic, the medicine and the caregiver – the treatment encompasses all these four.

kural.pope_couplet: Save in the scions of a noble house, you never findInstinctive sense of right and virtuous shame combined
kural.pope_exp: Consistency (of thought, word and deed) and fear (of sin) are conjointly natural only to the high-born
kural.kannan_exp: Those of good birth stand apart through their sense of justice and sense of shame that come naturally for them.

kural.pope_couplet: In these three things the men of noble birth fail not:In virtuous deed and truthful word, and chastened thought
kural.pope_exp: The high-born will never deviate from these three; good manners, truthfulness and modesty
kural.kannan_exp: Propriety, truth and modesty: those of good birth do not lapse on these three.

kural.pope_couplet: The smile, the gift, the pleasant word, unfailing courtesyThese are the signs, they say, of true nobility
kural.pope_exp: A cheerful countenance, liberality, pleasant words, and an unreviling disposition, these four are said to be the proper qualities of the truly high-born
kural.kannan_exp: Those born in a family that treasures truth internalize these four: smile, generosity, sweet words and not belittling anyone.

kural.pope_couplet: Millions on millions piled would never winThe men of noble race to soul-degrading sin
kural.pope_exp: Though blessed with immense wealth, the noble will never do anything unbecoming
kural.kannan_exp: Even if they are bound to gain millions, those of good lineage shall never stoop to do things beneath themselves.

kural.pope_couplet: Though stores for charity should fail within, the ancient raceWill never lose its old ancestral grace
kural.pope_exp: Though their means fall off, those born in ancient families, will not lose their character (for liberality)
kural.kannan_exp: Their ability to give may dwindle, but those of ancient lineage do not depart from their character.

kural.pope_couplet: Whose minds are set to live as fits their sire's unspotted fame,Stooping to low deceit, commit no deeds that gender shame
kural.pope_exp: Those who seek to preserve the irreproachable honour of their families will not viciously do what is detrimental thereto
kural.kannan_exp: Those who seek to live in harmony with their families, of flawless descent, do not do unworthy deeds spurred by vengeance and deceit.

kural.pope_couplet: The faults of men of noble race are seen by every eye,As spots on her bright orb that walks sublime the evening sky
kural.pope_exp: As spots on her bright orb that walks sublime the evening sky
kural.kannan_exp: Any fault in a person of good descent stands out like the wart on the moon of the sky.

kural.pope_couplet: If lack of love appear in those who bear some goodly name,'Twill make men doubt the ancestry they claim
kural.pope_exp: If one of a good family betrays want of affection, his descent from it will be called in question
kural.kannan_exp: If lack of compassion is seen while considering the welfare of others, aspersions are cast on their ancestry.

kural.pope_couplet: Of soil the plants that spring thereout will show the worth:The words they speak declare the men of noble birth
kural.pope_exp: As the sprout indicates the nature of the soil, (so) the speech of the noble indicates (that of one's birth)
kural.kannan_exp: The sprouting shoots betray the seed hidden in the soil; words spoken portray the nature of their families.

kural.pope_couplet: Who seek for good the grace of virtuous shame must know;Who seek for noble name to all must reverence show
kural.pope_exp: He who desires a good name must desire modesty; and he who desires (the continuance of) a family greatness must be submissive to all
kural.kannan_exp: If one cares for his wellbeing, he needs a sense of shame; if one cares for his family, he needs to be humble before anyone.

kural.pope_couplet: Though linked to splendours man no otherwise may gain,Reject each act that may thine honour's clearness stain
kural.pope_exp: Actions that would degrade (one's) family should not be done; though they may be so important that not doing them would end in death
kural.kannan_exp: It maybe essential and important, yet, let it go, if it is beneath your dignity.

kural.pope_couplet: Who seek with glory to combine honour's untarnished fame,Do no inglorious deeds, though men accord them glory's name
kural.pope_exp: Those who desire (to maintain their) honour, will surely do nothing dishonourable, even for the sake of fame
kural.kannan_exp: Fame and riches may beckon but they’d not do ignoble deeds, those who seek high-mindedness besides honour.

kural.pope_couplet: Bow down thy soul, with increase blest, in happy hour;Lift up thy heart, when stript of all by fortune's power
kural.pope_exp: In great prosperity humility is becoming; dignity, in great adversity
kural.kannan_exp: In times of prosperity, humility is needed; but during poverty, don your pride.

kural.pope_couplet: Like hairs from off the head that fall to earth,When fall'n from high estate are men of noble birth
kural.pope_exp: They who have fallen from their (high) position are like the hair which has fallen from the head
kural.kannan_exp: When people slip beneath their dignified state, they are lowly as hair fallen from the head.

kural.pope_couplet: If meanness, slight as 'abrus' grain, by men be wrought,Though like a hill their high estate, they sink to nought
kural.pope_exp: Even those who are exalted like a hill will be thought low, if they commit deeds that are debasing
kural.kannan_exp: A base act, as minor as a rosary pea, will make those, as towering as a mountain, to shrivel.

kural.pope_couplet: It yields no praise, nor to the land of Gods throws wide the gate:Why follow men who scorn, and at their bidding wait
kural.pope_exp: Why follow men who scorn, and at their bidding wait?
kural.kannan_exp: It leads not to earthly fame, nor to a divine land; why then must one scamper behind those who revile them.

kural.pope_couplet: Better 'twere said, 'He's perished!' than to gainThe means to live, following in foeman's train
kural.pope_exp: It is better for a man to be said of him that he died in his usual state than that he eked out his life by following those who disgraced him
kural.kannan_exp: Better to be known that he died without stooping low, than live by depending on those who humiliate him.

kural.pope_couplet: When high estate has lost its pride of honour meet,Is life, that nurses this poor flesh, as nectar sweet
kural.pope_exp: For the high-born to keep their body in life when their honour is gone will certainly not prove a remedy against death
kural.kannan_exp: Living on to preserve your body, when the greatness of your character is gone – is that an elixir of life?

kural.pope_couplet: Like the wild ox that, of its tuft bereft, will pine away,Are those who, of their honour shorn, will quit the light of day
kural.pope_exp: Those who give up (their) life when (their) honour is at stake are like the yark which kills itself at the loss of (even one of) its hairs
kural.kannan_exp: The kavarimaa will cease living if a shred of hair is lost; likewise, there are those who’ll shed their lives, if disgraced.

kural.pope_couplet: Who, when dishonour comes, refuse to live, their honoured memoryWill live in worship and applause of all the world for aye
kural.pope_exp: The world will (always) praise and adore the fame of the honourable who would rather die than suffer indignity
kural.kannan_exp: The world shall revere their fame, those who are proud enough to face death than ignominy.

kural.pope_couplet: The light of life is mental energy; disgrace is hisWho says, 'I 'ill lead a happy life devoid of this.'
kural.pope_exp: One's light is the abundance of one's courage; one's darkness is the desire to live destitute of such (a state of mind.)
kural.kannan_exp: Reputation rests on possession of passion; It’s a disgrace to strive to live if ‘tis foregone.

kural.pope_couplet: All men that live are one in circumstances of birth;Diversities of works give each his special worth
kural.pope_exp: All human beings agree as regards their birth but differ as regards their characteristics, because of the different qualities of their actions
kural.kannan_exp: All beings are born equal. Distinction Comes with differences in profession.

kural.pope_couplet: The men of lofty line, whose souls are mean, are never greatThe men of lowly birth, when high of soul, are not of low estate
kural.pope_exp: Though (raised) above, the base cannot become great; though (brought) low, the great cannot become base
kural.kannan_exp: Eminent in stature, but not eminent in deed, is no eminence Lowly in stature, but not lowly in deed, is no lowliness.

kural.pope_couplet: Like single-hearted women, greatness too,Exists while to itself is true
kural.pope_exp: Exists while to itself is true
kural.kannan_exp: Like women of virtue, greatness exists Due to steadfast adherence to its virtues.

kural.pope_couplet: The man endowed with greatness true,Rare deeds in perfect wise will do
kural.pope_exp: (Though reduced) the great will be able to perform, in the proper way, deeds difficult (for others to do)
kural.kannan_exp: Those who are bestowed with greatness Do deeds that aren’t commonplace.

kural.pope_couplet: 'As votaries of the truly great we will ourselves enroll,'Is thought that enters not the mind of men of little soul
kural.pope_exp: It is never in the nature of the base to seek the society of the great and partake of their nature
kural.kannan_exp: The petty do not have it in them, the foresight To embrace and emulate the great.

kural.pope_couplet: Whene'er distinction lights on some unworthy head,Then deeds of haughty insolence are bred
kural.pope_exp: Even nobility of birth, wealth and learning, if in (the possession of) the base, will (only) produce everincreasing pride
kural.kannan_exp: The undeserving, if eminence graces, Pompous, lowly conduct ensues.

kural.pope_couplet: Greatness humbly bends, but littleness alwaysSpreads out its plumes, and loads itself with praise
kural.pope_exp: The great will always humble himself; but the mean will exalt himself in self-admiration
kural.kannan_exp: Greatness has forever humility Pettiness wallows in vanity.

kural.pope_couplet: Greatness is absence of conceit; meanness, we deem,Riding on car of vanity supreme
kural.pope_exp: Freedom from conceit is (the nature of true) greatness; (while) obstinacy therein is (that of) meanness
kural.kannan_exp: Greatness is devoid of pride Pettiness is perfused with bombast.

kural.pope_couplet: Greatness will hide a neighbour's shame;Meanness his faults to all the world proclaim
kural.pope_exp: The great hide the faults of others; the base only divulge them
kural.kannan_exp: Greatness masks others’ failings Pettiness keeps wailing.

kural.pope_couplet: All goodly things are duties to the men, they sayWho set themselves to walk in virtue's perfect way
kural.pope_exp: It is said that those who are conscious of their duty and behave with a perfect goodness will regard as natural all that is good
kural.kannan_exp: For those who dutifully strive to be noble, To do all that’s good is seen as natural.

kural.pope_couplet: The good of inward excellence they claim,The perfect men; all other good is only good in name
kural.pope_exp: The only delight of the perfect is that of their goodness; all other (sensual) delights are not to be included among any (true) delights
kural.kannan_exp: Being good within, is nobility; All else is no quality.

kural.pope_couplet: Love, modesty, beneficence, benignant grace,With truth, are pillars five of perfect virtue's resting-place
kural.pope_exp: Affection, fear (of sin), benevolence, favour and truthfulness; these are the five pillars on which perfect goodness rests
kural.kannan_exp: Love, compunction, beneficence, compassion and truthfulness: On these five columns rests nobleness.

kural.pope_couplet: The type of 'penitence' is virtuous good that nothing slays;To speak no ill of other men is perfect virtue's praise
kural.pope_exp: Penance consists in the goodness that kills not , and perfection in the goodness that tells not others' faults
kural.kannan_exp: The virtue of the ascetic is to not kill any being; The virtue of the noble is to never resort to blaming.

kural.pope_couplet: Submission is the might of men of mighty acts; the sageWith that same weapon stills his foeman's rage
kural.pope_exp: Stooping (to inferiors) is the strength of those who can accomplish (an undertaking); and that is the weapon with which the great avert their foes
kural.kannan_exp: Humility is the vital capability of the capable: To convert foes, the weapon of the noble.

kural.pope_couplet: What is perfection's test? The equal mindTo bear repulse from even meaner men resigned
kural.pope_exp: The touch-stone of perfection is to receive a defeat even at the hands of one's inferiors
kural.kannan_exp: The mark of nobility, if you ask, Is to concede with grace, defeat by the underdog.

kural.pope_couplet: What fruit doth your perfection yield you, say!Unless to men who work you ill good repay
kural.pope_exp: Of what avail is perfect goodness if it cannot do pleasing things even to those who have pained (it) ?
kural.kannan_exp: Of what use is being noble If one can’t do good unto those who did evil.

kural.pope_couplet: To soul with perfect virtue's strength endued,Brings no disgrace the lack of every earthly good
kural.pope_exp: Poverty is no disgrace to one who abounds in good qualities
kural.kannan_exp: Poverty is no disgrace if you possess The strength of nobleness.

kural.pope_couplet: Call them of perfect virtue's sea the shore,Who, though the fates should fail, fail not for evermore
kural.pope_exp: Those who are said to be the shore of the sea of perfection will never change, though ages may change
kural.kannan_exp: Those known to be the ocean of nobility aren’t perturbed Even when there is the proverbial Flood.

kural.pope_couplet: The mighty earth its burthen to sustain must cease,If perfect virtue of the perfect men decrease
kural.pope_exp: If there is a defect in the character of the perfect, (even) the great world cannot bear (its) burden
kural.kannan_exp: If the nobility of the noble does erode, The vast earth cannot bear its load.

kural.pope_couplet: Who easy access give to every man, they say,Of kindly courtesy will learn with ease the way
kural.pope_exp: If one is easy of access to all, it will be easy for one to obtain the virtue called goodness
kural.kannan_exp: Affability with all will help achieve with ease The quality of being courteous.

kural.pope_couplet: Benevolence and high born dignity,These two are beaten paths of courtesy
kural.pope_exp: Affectionateness and birth in a good family, these two constitute what is called a proper behaviour to all
kural.kannan_exp: A kind heart and good heredity are considered To make the quality of being well-mannered.

kural.pope_couplet: Men are not one because their members seem alike to outward view;Similitude of kindred quality makes likeness true
kural.pope_exp: Resemblance of bodies is no resemblance of souls; true resemblance is the resemblance of qualities that attract
kural.kannan_exp: Physical resemblance makes not people similar Similar qualities make them similar.

kural.pope_couplet: Of men of fruitful life, who kindly benefits dispense,The world unites to praise the 'noble excellence.'
kural.pope_exp: The world applauds the character of those whose usefulness results from their equity and charity
kural.kannan_exp: Being likeable and righteous, they serve all- Their good character the world shall extol.

kural.pope_couplet: Contempt is evil though in sport They who man's nature know,E'en in their wrath, a courteous mind will show
kural.pope_exp: Reproach is painful to one even in sport; those (therefore) who know the nature of others exhibit (pleasing) qualities even when they are hated
kural.kannan_exp: One who discerns others’ nature and sees merit in foes, Won’t deride others for a laugh that causes many woes.

kural.pope_couplet: The world abides; for 'worthy' men its weight sustainWere it not so, 'twould fall to dust again
kural.pope_exp: The (way of the) world subsists by contact with the good; if not, it would bury itself in the earth and perish
kural.kannan_exp: The world exists because of courteous people Else it’ll perish by sinking in its own soil.

kural.pope_couplet: Though sharp their wit as file, as blocks they must remain,Whose souls are void of 'courtesy humane'
kural.pope_exp: He who is destitute of (true) human qualities (only) resembles a tree, though he may possess the sharpness of a file
kural.kannan_exp: But for humanity, they are but a tree, Though sharp as a rasp they may be.

kural.pope_couplet: Though men with all unfriendly acts and wrongs assail,'Tis uttermost disgrace in 'courtesy' to fail
kural.pope_exp: It is wrong (for the wise) not to exhibit (good) qualities even towards those who bearing no friendship (for them) do only what is hateful
kural.kannan_exp: Even with those, hostile, and callously act, Behaving ungraciously is a blot.

kural.pope_couplet: To him who knows not how to smile in kindly mirth,Darkness in daytime broods o'er all the vast and mighty earth
kural.pope_exp: To those who cannot rejoice, the wide world is buried darkness even in (broad) day light
kural.kannan_exp: For those with no faculty to have fun Darkness swamps the large earth despite the sun.

kural.pope_couplet: Like sweet milk soured because in filthy vessel poured,Is ample wealth in churlish man's unopened coffers stored
kural.pope_exp: The great wealth obtained by one who has no goodness will perish like pure milk spoilt by the
kural.kannan_exp: Good milk spoiled by the vessel that is stained Is wealth in the hands of the uncultured.

kural.pope_couplet: Who fills his house with ample store, enjoying none,Is dead Nought with the useless heap is done
kural.pope_exp: He who does not enjoy the immense riches he has heaped up in his house, is (to be reckoned as) dead, (for) there is nothing achieved (by him)
kural.kannan_exp: Wealth allover the house stashed but is not used Makes one impotent as if he is deceased.

kural.pope_couplet: Who giving nought, opines from wealth all blessing springs,Degraded birth that doting miser's folly brings
kural.pope_exp: He who knows that wealth yields every pleasure and yet is so blind as to lead miserly life will be born a demon
kural.kannan_exp: Wealth is all, thinking thus, clinging and being ungenerous, Is a delusion leading to a birth most inglorious.

kural.pope_couplet: Who lust to heap up wealth, but glory hold not dear,It burthens earth when on the stage of being they appear
kural.pope_exp: A burden to the earth are men bent on the acquisition of riches and not (true) fame
kural.kannan_exp: They seek to gain wealth but not fame, being mean: The presence of such men is earth’s burden.

kural.pope_couplet: Whom no one loves, when he shall pass away,What doth he look to leave behind, I pray
kural.pope_exp: What will the miser who is not liked (by any one) regard as his own (in the world to come) ?
kural.kannan_exp: What’d he think is the legacy he’ll leave, He who has nobody’s love?

kural.pope_couplet: Amid accumulated millions they are poor,Who nothing give and nought enjoy of all they store
kural.pope_exp: Those who neither give (to others) nor enjoy (their property) are (truly) destitute, though possessing immense riches
kural.kannan_exp: Many crores one may make, but it means nothing If one is neither spending nor giving.

kural.pope_couplet: Their ample wealth is misery to men of churlish heart,Who nought themselves enjoy, and nought to worthy men impart
kural.pope_exp: He who enjoys not (his riches) nor relieves the wants of the worthy is a disease to his wealth
kural.kannan_exp: Wealth is a malady, when oneself it doesn’t serve And to the deserving, one isn’t disposed to give.

kural.pope_couplet: Like woman fair in lonelihood who aged grows,Is wealth of him on needy men who nought bestows
kural.pope_exp: The wealth of him who never bestows anything on the destitute is like a woman of beauty growing old without a husband
kural.kannan_exp: A maiden of bounteous merit, being single, if greyed: Such is wealth that is not used to aid the deprived.

kural.pope_couplet: When he whom no man loves exults in great prosperity,'Tis as when fruits in midmost of the town some poisonous tree
kural.pope_exp: The wealth of him who is disliked (by all) is like the fruit-bearing of the etty tree in the midst of a town
kural.kannan_exp: Wealth of a person, who is loved by none, Is a toxic fruit tree in the middle of a town.

kural.pope_couplet: Who love abandon, self-afflict, and virtue's way forsakeTo heap up glittering wealth, their hoards shall others take
kural.pope_exp: To heap up glittering wealth, their hoards shall others take
kural.kannan_exp: Devoid of love and denying oneself, Wealth gained with no scruples, others shall seize.

kural.pope_couplet: 'Tis as when rain cloud in the heaven grows day,When generous wealthy man endures brief poverty
kural.pope_exp: The short-lived poverty of those who are noble and rich is like the clouds becoming poor (for a while)
kural.kannan_exp: When the famed wealthy go through poverty They resemble clouds that lost their bounty.

kural.pope_couplet: To shrink abashed from evil deed is 'generous shame';Other is that of bright-browed one of virtuous fame
kural.pope_exp: True modesty is the fear of (evil) deeds; all other modesty is (simply) the bashfulness of virtuous maids
kural.kannan_exp: Compunction is having scruples about one’s action Distinct from demureness of pretty-browed fine women.

kural.pope_couplet: Food, clothing, and other things alike all beings own;By sense of shame the excellence of men is known
kural.pope_exp: Food, clothing and the like are common to all men but modesty is peculiar to the good
kural.kannan_exp: Needs of food, dress et al are not dissimilar for all Compunction is the distinctive feature of good people.

kural.pope_couplet: All spirits homes of flesh as habitation claim,And perfect virtue ever dwells with shame
kural.pope_exp: As the body is the abode of the spirit, so the excellence of modesty is the abode of perfection
kural.kannan_exp: Food is the basis for all lives, the goodness Of compunction is the basis for nobleness.

kural.pope_couplet: And is not shame an ornament to men of dignity?Without it step of stately pride is piteous thing to see
kural.pope_exp: Is not the modesty ornament of the noble ? Without it, their haughtiness would be a pain (to others)
kural.kannan_exp: For the noble, having compunction is an adornment; Without it, ain’t their proud stride an ailment?

kural.pope_couplet: As home of virtuous shame by all the world the men are known,Who feel ashamed for others, guilt as for their own
kural.pope_exp: The world regards as the abode of modesty him who fear his own and other's guilt
kural.kannan_exp: If blame for others and self, moves one to the same sense of shame The world shall call them the home for compunction.

kural.pope_couplet: Unless the hedge of shame inviolate remain,For men of lofty soul the earth's vast realms no charms retain
kural.pope_exp: The great make modesty their barrier (of defence) and not the wide world
kural.kannan_exp: Great men desire not the vast world under their reign Without the protective fence of compunction.

kural.pope_couplet: The men of modest soul for shame would life an offering make,But ne'er abandon virtuous shame for life's dear sake
kural.pope_exp: The modest would rather lose their life for the sake of modesty than lose modesty for the sake of life
kural.kannan_exp: Their lives they may shed but never their scruples to save their lives They who by their scruples ever abide.

kural.pope_couplet: Though know'st no shame, while all around asha med must be:Virtue will shrink away ashamed of thee
kural.pope_exp: Virtue is likely to forsake him who shamelessly does what others are ashamed of
kural.kannan_exp: If what shames others doesn’t raise in him a qualm Virtue’ll flee him feeling that shame.

kural.pope_couplet: 'Twill race consume if right observance fail;'Twill every good consume if shamelessness prevail
kural.pope_exp: Want of manners injures one's family; but want of modesty injures one's character
kural.kannan_exp: The family is hurt if one breaches convention All good is spoilt if there is lack of compunction.

kural.pope_couplet: 'Tis as with strings a wooden puppet apes life's functions, whenThose void of shame within hold intercourse with men
kural.pope_exp: The actions of those who are without modesty at heart are like those of puppet moved by a string
kural.kannan_exp: The actions of those who, deep within, have no compunction Is akin to a stringed puppet seeming alive, an illusion.

kural.pope_couplet: Who says 'I'll do my work, nor slack my hand',His greatness, clothed with dignity supreme, shall stand
kural.pope_exp: There is no higher greatness than that of one saying I will not cease in my effort (to raise my family)
kural.kannan_exp: To proclaim, “I shall never take my hands off” to do one’s duty No acclaim can match that dignity.

kural.pope_couplet: The manly act and knowledge full, when these combineIn deed prolonged, then lengthens out the race's line
kural.pope_exp: One's family is raised by untiring perseverance in both effort and wise contrivances
kural.kannan_exp: Tasks one takes on with persistence and profound wisdom – The people shall prosper through them.

kural.pope_couplet: 'I'll make my race renowned,' if man shall say,With vest succinct the goddess leads the way
kural.pope_exp: The Deity will clothe itself and appear before him who resolves on raising his family
kural.kannan_exp: “I’ll serve my people,” for the one who so said God shall gird up his robes and rush to his aid.

kural.pope_couplet: Who labours for his race with unremitting pain,Without a thought spontaneously, his end will gain
kural.pope_exp: Those who are prompt in their efforts (to better their family) need no deliberation, such efforts will of themselves succeed
kural.kannan_exp: When for his kindred, one perseveres without respite: With no contriving, on its own, it’ll turn out right.

kural.pope_couplet: With blameless life who seeks to build his race's fame,The world shall circle him, and kindred claim
kural.pope_exp: People will eagerly seek the friendship of the prosperous soul who has raised his family without foul means
kural.kannan_exp: Doing no wrong, the one who serves his kin – The world shall embrace as its own.

kural.pope_couplet: Of virtuous manliness the world accords the praiseTo him who gives his powers, the house from which he sprang to raise
kural.pope_exp: A man's true manliness consists in making himself the head and benefactor of his family
kural.kannan_exp: One will be known for his imposing command when He takes command of the house where he was born.

kural.pope_couplet: The fearless hero bears the brunt amid the warrior throng;Amid his kindred so the burthen rests upon the strong
kural.pope_exp: Amid his kindred so the burthen rests upon the strong
kural.kannan_exp: Like the bravehearts do on a battlefield The ablest takes charge of the household.

kural.pope_couplet: Wait for no season, when you would your house uprear;'Twill perish, if you wait supine, or hold your honour dear
kural.pope_exp: As a family suffers by (one's) indolence and false dignity there is to be so season (good or bad) to those who strive to raise their family
kural.kannan_exp: To serve one’s people look not for the ripe hour Being lethargic and ego-centric makes all suffer.

kural.pope_couplet: Is not his body vase that various sorrows fill,Who would his household screen from every ill
kural.pope_exp: Is it only to suffering that his body is exposed who undertakes to preserve his family from evil ?
kural.kannan_exp: Is his body the bin for all stress Who shields his kin from distress?

kural.pope_couplet: When trouble the foundation saps the house must fall,If no strong hand be nigh to prop the tottering wall
kural.pope_exp: If there are none to prop up and maintain a family (in distress), it will fall at the stroke of the axe of misfortune
kural.kannan_exp: The people who have not a good man to lean on Shall fall with their base shorn by some affliction.

kural.pope_couplet: Howe'er they roam, the world must follow still the plougher's team;Though toilsome, culture of the ground as noblest toil esteem
kural.pope_exp: Agriculture, though laborious, is the most excellent (form of labour); for people, though they go about (in search of various employments), have at last to resort to the farmer
kural.kannan_exp: The world tails the plough despite other pursuit Even if one toils, farming remains foremost.

kural.pope_couplet: The ploughers are the linch-pin of the world; they bearThem up who other works perform, too weak its toils to share
kural.pope_exp: Agriculturists are (as it were) the linch-pin of the world for they support all other workers who cannot till the soil
kural.kannan_exp: Farmers are the linchpin of the world All others not farming, it does hold.

kural.pope_couplet: Who ploughing eat their food, they truly live:The rest to others bend subservient, eating what they give
kural.pope_exp: They alone live who live by agriculture; all others lead a cringing, dependent life
kural.kannan_exp: Only they live, who eat from what they plough Others follow, and to eat, they kowtow.

kural.pope_couplet: O'er many a land they 'll see their monarch reign,Whose fields are shaded by the waving grain
kural.pope_exp: Patriotic farmers desire to bring all other states under the control of their own king
kural.kannan_exp: Who bring their land under their crops’ shade Many states under their king’s reign shall bade.

kural.pope_couplet: They nothing ask from others, but to askers give,Who raise with their own hands the food on which they live
kural.pope_exp: Those whose nature is to live by manual labour will never beg but give something to those who beg
kural.kannan_exp: They never beg, nor deny others, givin’ what they seek Whose nature is to eat what they till and make.

kural.pope_couplet: For those who 've left what all men love no place is found,When they with folded hands remain who till the ground
kural.pope_exp: If the farmer's hands are slackened, even the ascetic state will fail
kural.kannan_exp: If tillers fold their hands still, sages who say “I’ve given up desire,” as such cannot stay.

kural.pope_couplet: Reduce your soil to that dry state, When ounce is quarter-ounce's weight;Without one handful of manure, Abundant crops you thus secure
kural.pope_exp: If the land is dried so as to reduce one ounce of earth to a quarter, it will grow plentifully even without a handful of manure
kural.kannan_exp: If one measure of soil, is turned fine and dried to a quarter, Good yield needs not a handful of manure.

kural.pope_couplet: To cast manure is better than to plough;Weed well; to guard is more than watering now
kural.pope_exp: Manuring is better than ploughing; after weeding, watching is better than watering (it)
kural.kannan_exp: Worthier than ploughing is to manure the field; Weeding done, worthier than watering is to secure the yield.

kural.pope_couplet: When master from the field aloof hath stood;Then land will sulk, like wife in angry mood
kural.pope_exp: If the owner does not (personally) attend to his cultivation, his land will behave like an angry wife and yield him no pleasure
kural.kannan_exp: If from the land, her master stays off Like a wife, she’ll sulk and start a tiff.

kural.pope_couplet: The earth, that kindly dame, will laugh to see,Men seated idle pleading poverty
kural.pope_exp: The maiden, Earth, will laugh at the sight of those who plead poverty and lead an idle life
kural.kannan_exp: Seeing them say, “We have not” and loiter The Fair Lady Earth scorns them with laughter.

kural.pope_couplet: You ask what sharper pain than poverty is known;Nothing pains more than poverty, save poverty alone
kural.pope_exp: There is nothing that afflicts (one) like poverty
kural.kannan_exp: If you ask, what torments more than poverty: Only poverty can torment more than poverty.

kural.pope_couplet: Malefactor matchless! poverty destroysThis world's and the next world's joys
kural.pope_exp: When cruel poverty comes on, it deprives one of both the present and future (bliss)
kural.kannan_exp: Poverty is a wretch; This life and the next does it snatch.

kural.pope_couplet: Importunate desire, which poverty men name,Destroys both old descent and goodly fame
kural.pope_exp: Hankering poverty destroys at once the greatness of (one's) ancient descent and (the dignity of one's) speech
kural.kannan_exp: Ancestral legacy and parlance crumble in totality Due to hankering caused by poverty.

kural.pope_couplet: From penury will spring, 'mid even those of noble race,Oblivion that gives birth to words that bring disgrace
kural.pope_exp: Even in those of high birth, poverty will produce the fault of uttering mean words
kural.kannan_exp: From the high-born too, vile words may be born When deprivation makes them so cast down.

kural.pope_couplet: From poverty, that grievous woe,Attendant sorrows plenteous grow
kural.pope_exp: The misery of poverty brings in its train many (more) miseries
kural.kannan_exp: From the one misery named penury Emanates many a worry.

kural.pope_couplet: Though deepest sense, well understood, the poor man's words convey,Their sense from memory of mankind will fade away
kural.pope_exp: The words of the poor are profitless, though they may be sound in thought and clear in expression
kural.kannan_exp: After deep reflection they may say words of deep essence Yet what the poor say may be seen to have no sense.

kural.pope_couplet: From indigence devoid of virtue's grace,The mother e'en that bare, estranged, will turn her face
kural.pope_exp: He that is reduced to absolute poverty will be regarded as a stranger even by his own mother
kural.kannan_exp: Poverty aligned to no virtue makes even one’s mother Who bore bore him, to see him as a misfit.

kural.pope_couplet: And will it come today as yesterday,The grief of want that eats my soul away
kural.pope_exp: Is the poverty that almost killed me yesterday, to meet me today too ?
kural.kannan_exp: Did not my privation kill me yesterday? Does it have to be back again today?

kural.pope_couplet: Amid the flames sleep may men's eyelids close,In poverty the eye knows no repose
kural.pope_exp: One may sleep in the midst of fire; but by no means in the midst of poverty
kural.kannan_exp: One may snatch a nap amidst raging fire But can not sleep a wink in poverty dire.

kural.pope_couplet: Unless the destitute will utterly themselves deny,They cause their neighbour's salt and vinegar to die
kural.pope_exp: The destitute poor, who do not renounce their bodies, only consume their neighbour's salt and water
kural.kannan_exp: When want does not make one give up desire It spells doom for salt and sour gruel next door.

kural.pope_couplet: When those you find from whom 'tis meet to ask,- for aid apply;Theirs is the sin, not yours, if they the gift deny
kural.pope_exp: If you meet with those that may be begged of, you may beg; (but) if they withhold (their gift) it is their blame and not yours
kural.kannan_exp: Seeks alms if you find those worthy of benefaction; If they refuse, blame is theirs and not yours.

kural.pope_couplet: Even to ask an alms may pleasure give,If what you ask without annoyance you receive
kural.pope_exp: Even begging may be pleasant, if what is begged for is obtained without grief (to him that begs)
kural.kannan_exp: Seeking alms causes us great delight If what is sought is got without any plight.

kural.pope_couplet: The men who nought deny, but know what's due, before their faceTo stand as suppliants affords especial grace
kural.pope_exp: There is even a beauty in standing before and begging of those who are liberal in their gifts and understand their duty (to beggars)
kural.kannan_exp: With ungrudging hearts, they view charity as a duty To stand before them and beg – there’s a beauty!

kural.pope_couplet: Like giving alms, may even asking pleasant seem,From men who of denial never even dream
kural.pope_exp: To beg of such as never think of withholding (their charity) even in their dreams, is in fact the same as giving (it oneself);
kural.kannan_exp: They know not withholding even in their dreams Same as giving it seems, asking them for alms.

kural.pope_couplet: Because on earth the men exist, who never say them nay,Men bear to stand before their eyes for help to pray
kural.pope_exp: As there are in the world those that give without refusing, there are (also) those that prefer to beg by simply standing before them
kural.kannan_exp: That the world has them who give and nothing conceal Is why others appear before them and for alms appeal.

kural.pope_couplet: It those you find from evil of 'denial' free,At once all plague of poverty will flee
kural.pope_exp: All the evil of begging will be removed at the sight of those who are far from the evil of refusing
kural.kannan_exp: When we see those without the folly of concealing Gone are all the ills of having nothing.

kural.pope_couplet: If men are found who give and no harsh words of scorn employ,The minds of askers, through and through, will thrill with joy
kural.pope_exp: Beggars rejoice exceedingly when they behold those who bestow (their alms) with kindness and courtesy
kural.kannan_exp: Seeing givers who do not mock and deride The heart delights and rejoices deep inside.

kural.pope_couplet: If askers cease, the mighty earth, where cooling fountains flow,Will be a stage where wooden puppets come and go
kural.pope_exp: If there were no beggars, (the actions done in) the cool wide world would only resemble the movement of a puppet
kural.kannan_exp: If there be no mendicants, this vast moist world Will resemble wooden puppets that come and go.

kural.pope_couplet: What glory will there be to men of generous soul,When none are found to love the askers' role
kural.pope_exp: What (praise) would there be to givers (of alms) if there were no beggars to ask for and reveive (them)
kural.kannan_exp: Ah, what is there to brag about those who give If there be none to seek and gladly receive.

kural.pope_couplet: Askers refused from wrath must stand aloof;The plague of poverty itself is ample proof
kural.pope_exp: He who begs ought not to be angry (at a refusal); for even the misery of (his own) poverty should be a sufficient reason (for so doing)
kural.kannan_exp: The denied mendicant should never feel indignant The pain of poverty is proof enough of its worth.

kural.pope_couplet: Ten million-fold 'tis greater gain, asking no alms to live,Even from those, like eyes in worth, who nought concealing gladly give
kural.pope_exp: Not to beg (at all) even from those excellent persons who cheerfully give without refusing, will do immense good
kural.kannan_exp: Not concealing, they give with joy, and are as dear as eyes; Yet, to resist asking even from them is worth crores.

kural.pope_couplet: If he that shaped the world desires that men should begging go,Through life's long course, let him a wanderer be and perish so
kural.pope_exp: If the Creator of the world has decreed even begging as a means of livelihood, may he too go abegging and perish
kural.kannan_exp: Having to beg for survival, if anyone is destined, The Maker of this world be damned.

kural.pope_couplet: Nothing is harder than the hardness that will say,'The plague of penury by asking alms we'll drive away.'
kural.pope_exp: There is no greater folly than the boldness with which one seeks to remedy the evils of poverty by begging (rather than by working)
kural.kannan_exp: Nothing can be more brazen than Banking on charity to end deprivation.

kural.pope_couplet: Who ne'er consent to beg in utmost need, their worthHas excellence of greatness that transcends the earth
kural.pope_exp: Even the whole world cannot sufficiently praise the dignity that would not beg even in the midst of destitution
kural.kannan_exp: No place is adequate to hold their nobility When, in direst straits, they seek no charity.

kural.pope_couplet: Nothing is sweeter than to taste the toil-won cheer,Though mess of pottage as tasteless as the water clear
kural.pope_exp: Even thin gruel is ambrosia to him who has obtained it by labour
kural.kannan_exp: Mere gruel made of clear water tastes sweetest When it is earned through earnest effort.

kural.pope_couplet: E'en if a draught of water for a cow you ask,Nought's so distasteful to the tongue as beggar's task
