kural.pope_exp: There is nothing more disgraceful to one's tongue than to use it in begging water even for a cow
kural.kannan_exp: Nothing but begging shames the tongue more Even if what is sought is water for the cow.

kural.pope_couplet: One thing I beg of beggars all, 'If beg ye may,Of those who hide their wealth, beg not, I pray.'
kural.pope_exp: I beseech all beggars and say, "If you need to beg, never beg of those who give unwillingly."
kural.kannan_exp: I beg of all beggars: beg if you must, But beg not from those who conceal.

kural.pope_couplet: The fragile bark of beggaryWrecked on denial's rock will lie
kural.pope_exp: The unsafe raft of begging will split when it strikes on the rock of refusal
kural.kannan_exp: The fragile boat of begging will be wrecked When it knocks against the rock of refusal.

kural.pope_couplet: The heart will melt away at thought of beggary,With thought of stern repulse 'twill perish utterly
kural.pope_exp: To think of (the evil of) begging is enough to melt one's heart; but to think of refusal is enough to break it
kural.kannan_exp: When I think of those who beg, my heart melts; When I think of those who refuse, it wilts.

kural.pope_couplet: E'en as he asks, the shamefaced asker dies;Where shall his spirit hide who help denies
kural.pope_exp: Saying "No" to a beggar takes away his life. (but as that very word will kill the refuser) where then would the latter's life hide itself ?
kural.kannan_exp: When one asks but is denied, his life departs; Where will he hide, the one who denies.

kural.pope_couplet: The base resemble men in outward form, I ween;But counterpart exact to them I've never seen
kural.pope_exp: The base resemble men perfectly (as regards form); and we have not seen such (exact) resemblance (among any other species)
kural.kannan_exp: By all appearances, the vile look so human; Such resemblance, I’ve nowhere seen.

kural.pope_couplet: Than those of grateful heart the base must luckier be,Their minds from every anxious thought are free
kural.pope_exp: The low enjoy more felicity than those who know what is good; for the former are not troubled with anxiety (as to the good)
kural.kannan_exp: More gifted than those who know the right course Are the vile: their hearts have no remorse.

kural.pope_couplet: The base are as the Gods; they tooDo ever what they list to do
kural.pope_exp: The base resemble the Gods; for the base act as they like
kural.kannan_exp: Those who are base are like Devas They are free to do as they please.

kural.pope_couplet: When base men those behold of conduct vile,They straight surpass them, and exulting smile
kural.pope_exp: The base feels proud when he sees persons whose acts meaner than his own
kural.kannan_exp: When they meet brutish people unfettered by scruples The lowest of the low take pride in surpassing them.

kural.pope_couplet: Fear is the base man's virtue; if that fail,Intense desire some little may avail
kural.pope_exp: (The principle of) behaviour in the mean is chiefly fear; if not, hope of gain, to some extent
kural.kannan_exp: The conformity of the vile is forced by fear And perhaps, a wee bit by desire.

kural.pope_couplet: The base are like the beaten drum; for, when they hearThe sound the secret out in every neighbour's ear
kural.pope_exp: The base are like a drum that is beaten, for they unburden to others the secrets they have heard
kural.kannan_exp: Like the broadcasting drum are the vile, Revealing everything confidential.

kural.pope_couplet: From off their moistened hands no clinging grain they shake,Unless to those with clenched fist their jaws who break
kural.pope_exp: The mean will not (even) shake off (what sticks to) their hands (soon after a meal) to any but those who would break their jaws with their clenched fists
kural.kannan_exp: The vile will not even wiggle their smeared dining fingers Unless their cheeks are cracked by a clenched fist.

kural.pope_couplet: The good to those will profit yield fair words who use;The base, like sugar-cane, will profit those who bruise
kural.pope_exp: The great bestow (their alms) as soon as they are informed; (but) the mean, like the sugar-cane, only when they are tortured to death
kural.kannan_exp: A word is enough to move the noble to help; Crushed like a sugarcane, the vile maybe of some use.

kural.pope_couplet: If neighbours clothed and fed he see, the baseIs mighty man some hidden fault to trace
kural.pope_exp: The base will bring an evil (accusation) against others, as soon as he sees them (enjoying) good food
kural.kannan_exp: When they see others well fed and well dressed The vile are adept at getting their flaws exposed.

kural.pope_couplet: For what is base man fit, if griefs assail?Himself to offer, there and then, for sale
kural.pope_exp: The base will hasten to sell themselves as soon as a calamity has befallen them. For what else are they fitted ?
kural.kannan_exp: When in trouble, themselves, the vile swiftly sell. What else do they have as a skill?

kural.pope_couplet: Goddess? or peafowl rare? She whose ears rich jewels wear,Is she a maid of human kind? All wildered is my mind
kural.pope_exp: Is this jewelled female a celestial, a choice peahen, or a human being ? My mind is perplexed

kural.pope_couplet: She of the beaming eyes, To my rash look her glance replies,As if the matchless goddess' hand Led forth an armed band
kural.pope_exp: This female beauty returning my looks is like a celestial maiden coming with an army to contend against me

kural.pope_couplet: Death's form I formerly Knew not; but now 'tis plain to me;He comes in lovely maiden's guise, With soul-subduing eyes
kural.pope_exp: I never knew before what is called Yama; I see it now; it is the eyes that carry on a great fight with (the help of) female qualities

kural.pope_couplet: In sweet simplicity, A woman's gracious form hath she;But yet those eyes, that drink my life, Are with the form at strife
kural.pope_exp: These eyes that seem to kill those who look at them are as it were in hostilities with this feminine simplicity

kural.pope_couplet: The light that on me gleams, Is it death's dart? or eye's bright beams?Or fawn's shy glance? All three appear In form of maiden here
kural.pope_exp: Is it Yama, (a pair of) eyes or a hind ?- Are not all these three in the looks of this maid ?

kural.pope_couplet: If cruel eye-brow's bow, Unbent, would veil those glances now;The shafts that wound this trembling heart Her eyes no more would dart
kural.pope_exp: Her eyes will cause (me) no trembling sorrow, if they are properly hidden by her cruel arched eyebrows

kural.pope_couplet: As veil o'er angry eyes Of raging elephant that lies,The silken cincture's folds invest This maiden's panting breast
kural.pope_exp: The cloth that covers the firm bosom of this maiden is (like) that which covers the eyes of a rutting elephant

kural.pope_couplet: Ah woe is me my might, That awed my foemen in the fight,By lustre of that beaming brow Borne down, lies broken now
kural.pope_exp: On her bright brow alone is destroyed even that power of mine that used to terrify the most fearless

kural.pope_couplet: Like tender fawn's her eye; Clothed on is she with modesty;What added beauty can be lent; By alien ornament
kural.pope_exp: Of what use are other jewels to her who is adorned with modesty, and the meek looks of a hind ?

kural.pope_couplet: The palm-tree's fragrant wine, To those who taste yields joys divine;But love hath rare felicity For those that only see
kural.pope_exp: Unlike boiled honey which yields delight only when it is drunk, love gives pleasure even when looked at

kural.pope_couplet: A double witchery have glances of her liquid eye;One glance is glance that brings me pain; the other heals again
kural.pope_exp: There are two looks in the dyed eyes of this (fair one); one causes pain, and the other is the cure thereof

kural.pope_couplet: The furtive glance, that gleams one instant bright,Is more than half of love's supreme delight
kural.pope_exp: A single stolen glance of her eyes is more than half the pleasure (of sexual embrace)

kural.pope_couplet: She looked, and looking drooped her head:On springing shoot of love 'its water shed
kural.pope_exp: She has looked (at men) and stooped (her head); and that (sign) waters as it were (the corn of) our love

kural.pope_couplet: I look on her: her eyes are on the ground the while:I look away: she looks on me with timid smile
kural.pope_exp: When I look, she looks down; when I do not, she looks and smiles gently

kural.pope_couplet: She seemed to see me not; but yet the maidHer love, by smiling side-long glance, betrayed
kural.pope_exp: She not only avoids a direct look at me, but looks as it were with a half-closed eye and smiles

kural.pope_couplet: Though with their lips affection they disown,Yet, when they hate us not, 'tis quickly known
kural.pope_exp: Though they may speak harshly as if they were strangers, the words of the friendly are soon understood

kural.pope_couplet: The slighting words that anger feign, while eyes their love revealAre signs of those that love, but would their love conceal
kural.pope_exp: Little words that are harsh and looks that are hateful are (but) the expressions of lovers who wish to act like strangers

kural.pope_couplet: I gaze, the tender maid relents the while;And, oh the matchless grace of that soft smile
kural.pope_exp: When I look, the pitying maid looks in return and smiles gently; and that is a comforting sign for me

kural.pope_couplet: The look indifferent, that would its love disguise,Is only read aright by lovers' eyes
kural.pope_exp: Both the lovers are capable of looking at each other in an ordinary way, as if they were perfect strangers

kural.pope_couplet: When eye to answering eye reveals the tale of love,All words that lips can say must useless prove
kural.pope_exp: The words of the mouths are of no use whatever, when there is perfect agreement between the eyes (of lovers)

kural.pope_couplet: All joys that senses five- sight, hearing, taste, smell, touch- can give,In this resplendent armlets-bearing damsel live
kural.pope_exp: The (simultaneous) enjoyment of the five senses of sight, hearing, taste, smell and touch can only be found with bright braceleted (women)

kural.pope_couplet: Disease and medicine antagonists we surely see;This maid, to pain she gives, herself is remedy
kural.pope_exp: The remedy for a disease is always something different (from it); but for the disease caused by this jewelled maid, she is herself the cure

kural.pope_couplet: Than rest in her soft arms to whom the soul is giv'n,Is any sweeter joy in his, the Lotus-eyed-one's heaven
kural.pope_exp: Can the lotus-eyed Vishnu's heaven be indeed as sweet to those who delight to sleep in the delicate arms of their beloved ?

kural.pope_couplet: Withdraw, it burns; approach, it soothes the pain;Whence did the maid this wondrous fire obtain
kural.pope_exp: From whence has she got this fire that burns when I withdraw and cools when I approach ?

kural.pope_couplet: In her embrace, whose locks with flowery wreaths are bound,Each varied form of joy the soul can wish is found
kural.pope_exp: Each varied form of joy the soul can wish is found

kural.pope_couplet: Ambrosia are the simple maiden's arms; when I attainTheir touch, my withered life puts forth its buds again
kural.pope_exp: The shoulders of this fair one are made of ambrosia, for they revive me with pleasure every time I embrace them

kural.pope_couplet: As when one eats from household store, with kindly graceSharing his meal: such is this golden maid's embrace
kural.pope_exp: The embraces of a gold-complexioned beautiful female are as pleasant as to dwell in one's own house and live by one's own (earnings) after distributing (a portion of it in charity)

kural.pope_couplet: Sweet is the strict embrace of those whom fond affection binds,Where no dissevering breath of discord entrance finds
kural.pope_exp: To ardent lovers sweet is the embrace that cannot be penetrated even by a breath of breeze

kural.pope_couplet: The jealous variance, the healing of the strife, reunion gained:These are the fruits from wedded love obtained
kural.pope_exp: Love quarrel, reconciliation and intercourse - these are the advantages reaped by those who marry for lust

kural.pope_couplet: The more men learn, the more their lack of learning they detect;'Tis so when I approach the maid with gleaming jewels decked
kural.pope_exp: As (one's) ignorance is discovered the more one learns, so does repeated intercourse with a welladorned female (only create a desire for more)

kural.pope_couplet: O flower of the sensitive plant! than theeMore tender's the maiden beloved by me
kural.pope_exp: May you flourish, O Anicham! you have a delicate nature But my beloved is more delicate than you

kural.pope_couplet: You deemed, as you saw the flowers, her eyes were as flowers, my soul,That many may see; it was surely some folly that over you stole
kural.pope_exp: O my soul, fancying that flowers which are seen by many can resemble her eyes, you become confused at the sight of them

kural.pope_couplet: As tender shoot her frame; teeth, pearls; around her odours blend;Darts are the eyes of her whose shoulders like the bambu bend
kural.pope_exp: The complexion of this bamboo-shouldered one is that of a shoot; her teeth, are pearls; her breath,

kural.pope_couplet: The lotus, seeing her, with head demiss, the ground would eye,And say, 'With eyes of her, rich gems who wears, we cannot vie.'
kural.pope_exp: If the blue lotus could see, it would stoop and look at the ground saying, "I can never resemble the eyes of this excellent jewelled one."

kural.pope_couplet: The flowers of the sensitive plant as a girdle around her she placed;The stems she forgot to nip off; they 'll weigh down the delicate waist
kural.pope_exp: No merry drums will be beaten for the (tender) waist of her who has adorned herself with the anicham without having removed its stem

kural.pope_couplet: The stars perplexed are rushing wildly from their spheres;For like another moon this maiden's face appears
kural.pope_exp: The stars have become confused in their places not being able to distinguish between the moon and the maid's countenance

kural.pope_couplet: In moon, that waxing waning shines, as sports appear,Are any spots discerned in face of maiden here
kural.pope_exp: Could there be spots in the face of this maid like those in the bright full moon ?

kural.pope_couplet: Farewell, O moon! If that thine orb could shineBright as her face, thou shouldst be love of mine
kural.pope_exp: If you can indeed shine like the face of women, flourish, O moon, for then would you be worth loving ?

kural.pope_couplet: If as her face, whose eyes are flowers, thou wouldst have charms for me,Shine for my eyes alone, O moon, shine not for all to see
kural.pope_exp: O moon, if you wish to resemble the face of her whose eyes are like (these) flowers, do not appear so as to be seen by all

kural.pope_couplet: The flower of the sensitive plant, and the down on the swan's white breast,As the thorn are harsh, by the delicate feet of this maiden pressed
kural.pope_exp: The anicham and the feathers of the swan are to the feet of females, like the fruit of the (thorny) Nerunji

kural.pope_couplet: The dew on her white teeth, whose voice is soft and low,Is as when milk and honey mingled flow
kural.pope_exp: The water which oozes from the white teeth of this soft speeched damsel is like a mixture of milk and honey

kural.pope_couplet: Between this maid and me the friendship kindIs as the bonds that soul and body bind
kural.pope_exp: The love between me and this damsel is like the union of body and soul

kural.pope_couplet: For her with beauteous brow, the maid I love, there place is none;To give her image room, O pupil of mine eye, begone
kural.pope_exp: O you image in the pupil (of my eye)! depart; there is no room for (my) fair-browed beloved

kural.pope_couplet: Life is she to my very soul when she draws nigh;Dissevered from the maid with jewels rare, I die
kural.pope_exp: My fair-jewelled one resembles the living soul (when she is in union with me), the dying soul when she leaves me

kural.pope_couplet: I might recall, if I could once forget; but from my heartHer charms fade not, whose eyes gleam like the warrior's dart
kural.pope_exp: If I had forgotten her who has bright battling eyes, I would have remembered (thee); but I never forget her (Thus says he to her maid)

kural.pope_couplet: My loved one's subtle form departs not from my eyes;I wink them not, lest I should pain him where he lies
kural.pope_exp: My lover would not depart from mine eyes; even if I wink, he would not suffer (from pain); he is so ethereal

kural.pope_couplet: My love doth ever in my eyes reside;I stain them not, fearing his form to hide
kural.pope_exp: As my lover abides in my eyes, I will not even paint them, for he would (then) have to conceal himself

kural.pope_couplet: Within my heart my lover dwells; from food I turnThat smacks of heat, lest he should feel it burn
kural.pope_exp: As my lover is in my heart, I am afraid of eating (anything) hot, for I know it would pain him

kural.pope_couplet: I fear his form to hide, nor close my eyes:'Her love estranged is gone!' the village cries
kural.pope_exp: I will not wink, knowing that if I did, my lover would hide himself; and for this reason, this town says, he is unloving

kural.pope_couplet: Rejoicing in my very soul he ever lies;'Her love estranged is gone far off!' the village cries
kural.pope_exp: My lover dwells in my heart with perpetual delight; but the town says he is unloving and (therefore) dwells afar

kural.pope_couplet: To those who 've proved love's joy, and now afflicted mourn,Except the helpful 'horse of palm', no other strength remains
kural.pope_exp: To those who after enjoyment of sexual pleasure suffer (for want of more), there is no help so efficient as the palmyra horse

kural.pope_couplet: My body and my soul, that can no more endure,Will lay reserve aside, and mount the 'horse of palm'
kural.pope_exp: Having got rid of shame, the suffering body and soul save themselves on the palmyra horse

kural.pope_couplet: I once retained reserve and seemly manliness;To-day I nought possess but lovers' 'horse of palm'
kural.pope_exp: Modesty and manliness were once my own; now, my own is the palmyra horse that is ridden by the lustful

kural.pope_couplet: Love's rushing tide will sweep away the raftOf seemly manliness and shame combined
kural.pope_exp: The raft of modesty and manliness, is, alas, carried-off by the strong current of lust

kural.pope_couplet: The maid that slender armlets wears, like flowers entwined,Has brought me 'horse of palm,' and pangs of eventide
kural.pope_exp: She with the small garland-like bracelets has given me the palmyra horse and the sorrow that is endured at night

kural.pope_couplet: Of climbing 'horse of palm' in midnight hour, I think;My eyes know no repose for that same simple maid
kural.pope_exp: Mine eyes will not close in sleep on your mistress's account; even at midnight will I think of mounting the palmyra horse

kural.pope_couplet: There's nought of greater worth than woman's long-enduring soul,Who, vexed by love like ocean waves, climbs not the 'horse of palm'
kural.pope_exp: There is nothing so noble as the womanly nature that would not ride the palmyra horse, though plunged a sea of lust

kural.pope_couplet: In virtue hard to move, yet very tender, too, are we;Love deems not so, would rend the veil, and court publicity
kural.pope_exp: Even the Lust (of women) transgresses its secrecy and appears in public, forgetting that they are too chaste and liberal (to be overcome by it)

kural.pope_couplet: 'There's no one knows my heart,' so says my love,And thus, in public ways, perturbed will rove
kural.pope_exp: And thus, in public ways, perturbed will rove

kural.pope_couplet: Before my eyes the foolish make a mock of me,Because they ne'er endured the pangs I now must drie
kural.pope_exp: Even strangers laugh (at us) so as to be seen by us, for they have not suffered

kural.pope_couplet: By this same rumour's rise, my precious life stands fast;Good fortune grant the many know this not
kural.pope_exp: My precious life is saved by the raise of rumour, and this, to my good luck no others are aware of

kural.pope_couplet: The village hath to us this rumour giv'n, that makes her mine;Unweeting all the rareness of the maid with flower-like eyne
kural.pope_exp: Not knowing the value of her whose eyes are like flowers this town has got up a rumour about me

kural.pope_couplet: The rumour spread within the town, is it not gain to me?It is as though that were obtained that may not be
kural.pope_exp: Will I not get a rumour that is known to the (whole) town ? For what I have not got is as if I had got it (already)

kural.pope_couplet: The rumour rising makes my love to rise;My love would lose its power and languish otherwise
kural.pope_exp: Rumour increases the violence of my passion; without it it would grow weak and waste away

kural.pope_couplet: The more man drinks, the more he ever drunk would be;The more my love's revealed, the sweeter 'tis to me
kural.pope_exp: As drinking liquor is delightful (to one) whenever one is in mirth, so is lust delightful to me whenever it is the subject of rumour

kural.pope_couplet: I saw him but one single day: rumour spreads soonAs darkness, when the dragon seizes on the moon
kural.pope_exp: It was but a single day that I looked on (my lover); but the rumour thereof has spread like the seizure of the moon by the serpent

kural.pope_couplet: My anguish grows apace: the town's reportManures it; my mother's word doth water it
kural.pope_exp: This malady (of lust) is manured by the talk of women and watered by the (harsh) words of my mother

kural.pope_couplet: With butter-oil extinguish fire! 'Twill proveHarder by scandal to extinguish love
kural.pope_exp: To say that one could extinguish passion by rumour is like extinguishing fire with ghee

kural.pope_couplet: When he who said 'Fear not!' hath left me blamed,While many shrink, can I from rumour hide ashamed
kural.pope_exp: When the departure of him who said "fear not" has put me to shame before others, why need I be ashamed of scandal

kural.pope_couplet: If we desire, who loves will grant what we require;This town sends forth the rumour we desire
kural.pope_exp: The rumour I desire is raised by the town (itself); and my lover would if desired consent (to my following him)

kural.pope_couplet: If you will say, 'I leave thee not,' then tell me so;Of quick return tell those that can survive this woe
kural.pope_exp: If it is not departure, tell me; but if it is your speedy return, tell it to those who would be alive then

kural.pope_couplet: It once was perfect joy to look upon his face;But now the fear of parting saddens each embrace
kural.pope_exp: His very look was once pleasing; but (now) even intercourse is painful through fear of separation

kural.pope_couplet: To trust henceforth is hard, if ever he depart,E'en he, who knows his promise and my breaking heart
kural.pope_exp: As even the lover who understands (everything) may at times depart, confidence is hardly possible

kural.pope_couplet: If he depart, who fondly said, 'Fear not,' what blame's incurredBy those who trusted to his reassuring word
kural.pope_exp: If he who bestowed his love and said "fear not" should depart, will it be the fault of those who believed in (his) assuring words ?

kural.pope_couplet: If you would guard my life, from going him restrainWho fills my life! If he depart, hardly we meet again
kural.pope_exp: If you would save (my life), delay the departure of my destined (husband); for if he departs, intercourse will become impossible

kural.pope_couplet: To cherish longing hope that he should ever gracious be,Is hard, when he could stand, and of departure speak to me
kural.pope_exp: Is hard, when he could stand, and of departure speak to me

kural.pope_couplet: The bracelet slipping from my wrist announced beforeDeparture of the Prince that rules the ocean shore
kural.pope_exp: Do not the rings that begin to slide down my fingers forebode the separation of my lord ?

kural.pope_couplet: 'Tis sad to sojourn in the town where no kind kinsmen dwell;'Tis sadder still to bid a friend beloved farewell
kural.pope_exp: Painful is it to live in a friendless town; but far more painful is it to part from one's lover

kural.pope_couplet: Fire burns the hands that touch; but smart of loveWill burn in hearts that far away remove
kural.pope_exp: Fire burns when touched; but, like the sickness of love, can it also burn when removed ?

kural.pope_couplet: Sorrow's sadness meek sustaining, Driving sore distress away,Separation uncomplaining Many bear the livelong day
kural.pope_exp: As if there were many indeed that can consent to the impossible, kill their pain, endure separation and yet continue to live afterwards

kural.pope_couplet: I would my pain conceal, but see! it surging swells,As streams to those that draw from ever-springing wells
kural.pope_exp: I would hide this pain from others; but it (only) swells like a spring to those who drain it

kural.pope_couplet: I cannot hide this pain of mine, yet shame restrainsWhen I would tell it out to him who caused my pains
kural.pope_exp: I cannot conceal this pain, nor can I relate it without shame to him who has caused it

kural.pope_couplet: My soul, like porter's pole, within my wearied frame,Sustains a two-fold burthen poised, of love and shame
kural.pope_exp: (Both) lust and shame, with my soul for their shoulder pole balance themselves on a body that cannot bear them

kural.pope_couplet: A sea of love, 'tis true, I see stretched out before,But not the trusty bark that wafts to yonder shore
kural.pope_exp: There is indeed a flood of lust; but there is no raft of safety to cross it with

kural.pope_couplet: Who work us woe in friendship's trustful hour,What will they prove when angry tempests lower
kural.pope_exp: What will they prove when angry tempests lower?

kural.pope_couplet: A happy love 's sea of joy; but mightier sorrows rollFrom unpropitious love athwart the troubled soul
kural.pope_exp: The pleasure of lust is (as great as) the sea; but the pain of lust is far greater

kural.pope_couplet: I swim the cruel tide of love, and can no shore descry,In watches of the night, too, 'mid the waters, only I
kural.pope_exp: I have swam across the terrible flood of lust, but have not seen its shore; even at midnight I am alone; still I live

kural.pope_couplet: All living souls in slumber soft she steeps;But me alone kind night for her companing keeps
kural.pope_exp: The night which graciously lulls to sleep all living creatures, has me alone for her companion

kural.pope_couplet: More cruel than the cruelty of him, the cruel one,In these sad times are lengthening hours of night I watch alone
kural.pope_exp: The long nights of these days are far more cruel than the heartless one who is torturing me

kural.pope_couplet: When eye of mine would as my soul go forth to him,It knows not how through floods of its own tears to swim
kural.pope_exp: Could mine eyes travel like my thoughts to the abode (of my absent lord), they would not swim in this flood of tears

kural.pope_couplet: They showed me him, and then my endless painI saw: why then should weeping eyes complain
kural.pope_exp: As this incurable malady has been caused by my eyes which showed (him) to me, why should they now weep for (him)

kural.pope_couplet: How glancing eyes, that rash unweeting looked that day,With sorrow measureless are wasting now away
kural.pope_exp: The dyed eyes that (then) looked without foresight, why should they now endure sorrow, without feeling sharply (their own fault)

kural.pope_couplet: The eyes that threw such eager glances round erewhileAre weeping now. Such folly surely claims a smile
kural.pope_exp: They themselves looked eagerly (on him) and now they weep. Is not this to be laughed at ?

kural.pope_couplet: Those eyes have wept till all the fount of tears is dry,That brought upon me pain that knows no remedy
kural.pope_exp: These painted eyes have caused me a lasting mortal disease; and now they can weep no more, the tears having dried up

kural.pope_couplet: The eye that wrought me more than sea could hold of woes,Is suffering pangs that banish all repose
kural.pope_exp: Mine eyes have caused me a lust that is greater than the sea and (they themselves) endure the torture of sleeplessness

kural.pope_couplet: Oho! how sweet a thing to see! the eyeThat wrought this pain, in the same gulf doth lie
kural.pope_exp: The eyes that have given me this disease have themselves been seized with this (suffering) Oh! I am much delighted

kural.pope_couplet: Aching, aching, let those exhaust their stream,That melting, melting, that day gazed on him
kural.pope_exp: The eyes that became tender and gazed intently on him, may they suffer so much as to dry up the fountain of their tears

kural.pope_couplet: Who loved me once, onloving now doth here remain;Not seeing him, my eye no rest can gain
kural.pope_exp: He is indeed here who loved me with his lips but not with his heart but mine eyes suffer from not seeing him

kural.pope_couplet: When he comes not, all slumber flies; no sleep when he is there;Thus every way my eyes have troubles hard to bear
kural.pope_exp: When he is away they do not sleep; when he is present they do not sleep; in either case, mine eyes endure unbearable agony

kural.pope_couplet: It is not hard for all the town the knowledge to obtain,When eyes, as mine, like beaten tambours, make the mystery plain
kural.pope_exp: It is not difficult for the people of this place to understand the secret of those whose eyes, like mine, are as it were beaten drums

kural.pope_couplet: I willed my lover absent should remain;Of pining's sickly hue to whom shall I complain
kural.pope_exp: I who (then) consented to the absence of my loving lord, to whom can I (now) relate the fact of my having turned sallow

kural.pope_couplet: 'He gave': this sickly hue thus proudly speaks,Then climbs, and all my frame its chariot makes
kural.pope_exp: Sallowness, as if proud of having been caused by him, would now ride on my person

kural.pope_couplet: Of comeliness and shame he me bereft,While pain and sickly hue, in recompense, he left
kural.pope_exp: He has taken (away) my beauty and modesty, and given me instead disease and sallowness

kural.pope_couplet: I meditate his words, his worth is theme of all I say,This sickly hue is false that would my trust betray
kural.pope_exp: I think (of him); and what I speak about is but his excellence; still is there sallowness; and this is deceitful

kural.pope_couplet: My lover there went forth to roam;This pallor of my frame usurps his place at home
kural.pope_exp: Just as my lover departed then, did not sallowness spread here on my person ?

kural.pope_couplet: As darkness waits till lamp expires, to fill the place,This pallor waits till I enjoy no more my lord's embrace
kural.pope_exp: Just as darkness waits for the failing light; so does sallowness wait for the laxity of my husband's intercourse

kural.pope_couplet: I lay in his embrace, I turned unwittingly;Forthwith this hue, as you might grasp it, came on me
kural.pope_exp: I who was in close embrace just turned aside and the moment I did so, sallowness came on me like something to be seized on

kural.pope_couplet: On me, because I pine, they cast a slur;But no one says, 'He first deserted her.'
kural.pope_exp: Besides those who say "she has turned sallow" there are none who say "he has forsaken her"

kural.pope_couplet: Well let my frame, as now, be sicklied o'er with pain,If he who won my heart's consent, in good estate remain
kural.pope_exp: If he is clear of guilt who has conciliated me (to his departure) let my body suffer its due and turn sallow

kural.pope_couplet: 'Tis well, though men deride me for my sickly hue of pain;If they from calling him unkind, who won my love, refrain
kural.pope_exp: It would be good to be said of me that I have turned sallow, if friends do not reproach with unkindness him who pleased me (then)

kural.pope_couplet: The bliss to be beloved by those they love who gains,Of love the stoneless, luscious fruit obtains
kural.pope_exp: The women who are beloved by those whom they love, have they have not got the stone-less fruit of sexual delight ?

kural.pope_couplet: As heaven on living men showers blessings from above,Is tender grace by lovers shown to those they love
kural.pope_exp: The bestowal of love by the beloved on those who love them is like the rain raining (at the proper season) on those who live by it

kural.pope_couplet: Who love and are beloved to them aloneBelongs the boast, 'We've made life's very joys our own.'
kural.pope_exp: The pride that says "we shall live" suits only those who are loved by their beloved (husbands)

kural.pope_couplet: Those well-beloved will luckless prove,Unless beloved by those they love
kural.pope_exp: Even those who are esteemed (by other women) are devoid of excellence, if they are not loved by their beloved

kural.pope_couplet: From him I love to me what gain can be,Unless, as I love him, he loveth me
kural.pope_exp: He who is beloved by me, what will he do to me, if I am not beloved by him ?

kural.pope_couplet: Love on one side is bad; like balanced loadBy porter borne, love on both sides is good
kural.pope_exp: Lust, like the weight of the KAVADI, pains if it lies in one end only but pleases if it is in both

kural.pope_couplet: While Kaman rushes straight at me alone,Is all my pain and wasting grief unknown
kural.pope_exp: Would not cupid who abides and contends in one party (only) witness the pain and sorrow (in that party)?

kural.pope_couplet: Who hear from lover's lips no pleasant word from day to day,Yet in the world live out their life,- no braver souls than they
kural.pope_exp: There is no one in the world so hard-hearted as those who can live without receiving (even) a kind word from their beloved

kural.pope_couplet: Though he my heart desires no grace accords to me,Yet every accent of his voice is melody
kural.pope_exp: Though my beloved bestows no love on one, still are his words sweet to my ears

kural.pope_couplet: Tell him thy pain that loves not thee?Farewell, my soul, fill up the sea
kural.pope_exp: Live, O my soul, would you who relate your great sorrow to strangers, try rather to fill up your own sea (of sorrow)

kural.pope_couplet: From thought of her unfailing gladness springs,Sweeter than palm-rice wine the joy love brings
kural.pope_exp: Sexuality is sweeter than liquor, because when remembered, it creates a most rapturous delight

kural.pope_couplet: How great is love! Behold its sweetness past belief!Think on the lover, and the spirit knows no grief
kural.pope_exp: Even to think of one's beloved gives one no pain Sexuality, in any degree, is always delightful

kural.pope_couplet: A fit of sneezing threatened, but it passed away;He seemed to think of me, but do his fancies stray
kural.pope_exp: I feel as if I am going to sneeze but do not, and (therefore) my beloved is about to think (of me) but does not

kural.pope_couplet: Have I a place within his heart!From mine, alas! he never doth depart
kural.pope_exp: He continues to abide in my soul, do I likewise abide in his ?

kural.pope_couplet: Me from his heart he jealously excludes:Hath he no shame who ceaseless on my heart intrudes
kural.pope_exp: He who has imprisoned me in his soul, is he ashamed to enter incessantly into mine

kural.pope_couplet: How live I yet? I live to ponder o'erThe days of bliss with him that are no more
kural.pope_exp: I live by remembering my (former) intercourse with him; if it were not so, how could I live ?

kural.pope_couplet: If I remembered not what were I then? And yet,The fiery smart of what my spirit knows not to forget
kural.pope_exp: I have never forgotten (the pleasure); even to think of it burns my soul; could I live, if I should ever forget it ?

kural.pope_couplet: My frequent thought no wrath excites It is not so?This honour doth my love on me bestow
kural.pope_exp: He will not be angry however much I may think of him; is it not so much the delight my beloved

kural.pope_couplet: Dear life departs, when his ungracious deeds I ponder o'er,Who said erewhile, 'We're one for evermore'
kural.pope_exp: My precious life is wasting away by thinking too much on the cruelty of him who said we were not different

kural.pope_couplet: Set not; so may'st thou prosper, moon! that eyes may seeMy love who went away, but ever bides with me
kural.pope_exp: May you live, O Moon! Do not set, that I mine see him who has departed without quitting my soul

kural.pope_couplet: It came and brought to me, that nightly vision rare,A message from my love,- what feast shall I prepare
kural.pope_exp: Where with shall I feast the dream which has brought me my dear one's messenger ?

kural.pope_couplet: If my dark, carp-like eye will close in sleep, as I implore,The tale of my long-suffering life I'll tell my loved one o'er
kural.pope_exp: If my fish-like painted eyes should, at my begging, close in sleep, I could fully relate my sufferings to my lord

kural.pope_couplet: Him, who in waking hour no kindness shows,In dreams I see; and so my lifetime goes
kural.pope_exp: My life lasts because in my dream I behold him who does not favour me in my waking hours

kural.pope_couplet: Some pleasure I enjoy when him who loves not meIn waking hours, the vision searches out and makes me see
kural.pope_exp: There is pleasure in my dream, because in it I seek and obtain him who does not visit me in my wakefulness

kural.pope_couplet: As what I then beheld in waking hour was sweet,So pleasant dreams in hour of sleep my spirit greet
kural.pope_exp: I saw him in my waking hours, and then it was pleasant; I see him just now in my dream, and it is (equally) pleasant

kural.pope_couplet: And if there were no waking hour, my loveIn dreams would never from my side remove
kural.pope_exp: Were there no such thing as wakefulness, my beloved (who visited me) in my dream would not depart from me

kural.pope_couplet: The cruel one, in waking hour, who all ungracious seems,Why should he thus torment my soul in nightly dreams
kural.pope_exp: The cruel one who would not favour me in my wakefulness, what right has he to torture me in my dreams?

kural.pope_couplet: And when I sleep he holds my form embraced;And when I wake to fill my heart makes haste
kural.pope_exp: When I am asleep he rests on my shoulders, (but) when I awake he hastens into my soul

kural.pope_couplet: In dreams who ne'er their lover's form perceive,For those in waking hours who show no love will grieve
kural.pope_exp: They who have no dear ones to behold in their dreams blame him who visits me not in my waking hours

kural.pope_couplet: They say, that he in waking hours has left me lone;In dreams they surely see him not,- these people of the town;
kural.pope_exp: The women of this place say he has forsaken me in my wakefulness I think they have not seen him visit me in my dreams

kural.pope_couplet: Thou art not evening, but a spear that doth devourThe souls of brides; farewell, thou evening hour
kural.pope_exp: Live, O you evening are you (the former) evening? No, you are the season that slays (married) women

kural.pope_couplet: Thine eye is sad; Hail, doubtful hour of eventide!Of cruel eye, as is my spouse, is too thy bride
kural.pope_exp: A long life to you, O dark evening! You are sightless Is your help-mate (also) as hard-hearted as mine

kural.pope_couplet: With buds of chilly dew wan evening's shade enclose;My anguish buds space and all my sorrow grows
kural.pope_exp: The evening that (once) came in with trembling and dimness (now) brings me an aversion for life and increasing sorrow

kural.pope_couplet: When absent is my love, the evening hour descends,As when an alien host to field of battle wends
kural.pope_exp: In the absence of my lover, evening comes in like slayers on the field of slaughter

kural.pope_couplet: O morn, how have I won thy grace? thou bring'st reliefO eve, why art thou foe! thou dost renew my grief
kural.pope_exp: O eve, why art thou foe! thou dost renew my grief

kural.pope_couplet: The pangs that evening brings I never knew,Till he, my wedded spouse, from me withdrew
kural.pope_exp: Previous to my husband's departure, I know not the painful nature of evening

kural.pope_couplet: My grief at morn a bud, all day an opening flower,Full-blown expands in evening hour
kural.pope_exp: This malady buds forth in the morning, expands all day long and blossoms in the evening

kural.pope_couplet: The shepherd's pipe is like a murderous weapon, to my ear,For it proclaims the hour of ev'ning's fiery anguish near
kural.pope_exp: The shepherd's flute now sounds as a fiery forerunner of night, and is become a weapon that slays (me)

kural.pope_couplet: If evening's shades, that darken all my soul, extend;From this afflicted town will would of grief ascend
kural.pope_exp: When night comes on confusing (everyone's) mind, the (whole) town will lose its sense and be plunged in sorrow

kural.pope_couplet: This darkening eve, my darkling soul must perish utterly;Remembering him who seeks for wealth, but seeks not me
kural.pope_exp: My (hitherto) unextinguished life is now lost in this bewildering night at the thought of him who has the nature of wealth

kural.pope_couplet: Thine eyes grown dim are now ashamed the fragrant flow'rs to see,Thinking on him, who wand'ring far, leaves us in misery
kural.pope_exp: While we endure the unbearable sorrow, your eyes weep for him who is gone afar, and shun (the sight of) fragrant flowers

kural.pope_couplet: The eye, with sorrow wan, all wet with dew of tears,As witness of the lover's lack of love appears
kural.pope_exp: The discoloured eyes that shed tears profusely seem to betray the unkindness of our beloved

kural.pope_couplet: These withered arms, desertion's pangs abundantly display,That swelled with joy on that glad nuptial day
kural.pope_exp: The shoulders that swelled on the day of our union (now) seem to announce our separation clearly (to the public)

kural.pope_couplet: When lover went, then faded all their wonted charms,And armlets' golden round slips off from these poor wasted arms
kural.pope_exp: In the absence of your consort, your shoulders having lost their former beauty and fulness, your bracelets of pure gold have become loose

kural.pope_couplet: These wasted arms, the bracelet with their wonted beauty gone,The cruelty declare of that most cruel one
kural.pope_exp: The (loosened) bracelets, and the shoulders from which the old beauty has faded, relate the cruelty of the pitiless one

kural.pope_couplet: I grieve, 'tis pain to me to hear him cruel chid,Because the armlet from my wasted arm has slid
kural.pope_exp: I am greatly pained to hear you call him a cruel man, just because your shoulders are reduced and your bracelets loosened

kural.pope_couplet: My heart! say ought of glory wilt thou gain,If to that cruel one thou of thy wasted arms complain
kural.pope_exp: Can you O my soul! gain glory by relating to the (so-called) cruel one the clamour of my fading shoulders?

kural.pope_couplet: One day the fervent pressure of embracing arms I checked,Grew wan the forehead of the maid with golden armlet decked
kural.pope_exp: When I once loosened the arms that were in embrace, the forehead of the gold-braceleted women turned sallow

kural.pope_couplet: As we embraced a breath of wind found entrance there;The maid's large liquid eyes were dimmed with care
kural.pope_exp: When but a breath of breeze penetrated our embrace, her large cool eyes became sallow

kural.pope_couplet: The dimness of her eye felt sorrow now,Beholding what was done by that bright brow
kural.pope_exp: Was it at the sight of what the bright forehead had done that the sallowness of her eyes became sad?

kural.pope_couplet: My heart, canst thou not thinking of some med'cine tell,Not any one, to drive away this grief incurable
kural.pope_exp: O my soul, will you not think and tell me some medicine be it what it may, that can cure this incurable malady?

kural.pope_couplet: Since he loves not, thy smartIs folly, fare thee well my heart
kural.pope_exp: Is folly, fare thee well my heart!

kural.pope_couplet: What comes of sitting here in pining thought, O heart? He knowsNo pitying thought, the cause of all these wasting woes
kural.pope_exp: O my soul! why remain (here) and suffer thinking (of him)? There are no lewd thoughts (of you) in him who has caused you this disease of sorrow

kural.pope_couplet: O rid me of these eyes, my heart; for they,Longing to see him, wear my life away
kural.pope_exp: O my soul! take my eyes also with you, (if not), these would eat me up (in their desire) to see him

kural.pope_couplet: O heart, as a foe, can I abandon utterlyHim who, though I long for him, longs not for me
kural.pope_exp: O my soul! can he who loves not though he is beloved, be forsaken saying he hates me (now)?

kural.pope_couplet: My heart, false is the fire that burns; thou canst not wrath maintain,If thou thy love behold, embracing, soothing all thy pain
kural.pope_exp: O my soul! when you see the dear one who remove dislike by intercourse, you are displeased and continue to be so Nay, your displeasure is (simply) false

kural.pope_couplet: Or bid thy love, or bid thy shame depart;For me, I cannot bear them both, my worthy heart
kural.pope_exp: O my good soul, give up either lust or honour, as for me I can endure neither

kural.pope_couplet: Thou art befooled, my heart, thou followest him who flees from thee;And still thou yearning criest: 'He will nor pity show nor love to me.'
kural.pope_exp: You are a fool, O my soul! to go after my departed one, while you mourn that he is not kind enough to favour you

kural.pope_couplet: My heart! my lover lives within my mind;Roaming, whom dost thou think to find
kural.pope_exp: O my soul! to whom would you repair, while the dear one is within yourself?

kural.pope_couplet: If I should keep in mind the man who utterly renounces me,My soul must suffer further loss of dignity
kural.pope_exp: If I retain in my heart him who has left me without befriending me, I shall lose even the (inward) beauty that remains

kural.pope_couplet: Of womanly reserve love's axe breaks through the door,Barred by the bolt of shame before
kural.pope_exp: The axe of lust can break the door of chastity which is bolted with the bolt of modesty

kural.pope_couplet: What men call love is the one thing of merciless power;It gives my soul no rest, e'en in the midnight hour
kural.pope_exp: Even at midnight is my mind worried by lust, and this one thing, alas! is without mercy

kural.pope_couplet: I would my love conceal, but like a sneezeIt shows itself, and gives no warning sign
kural.pope_exp: I would conceal my lust, but alas, it yields not to my will but breaks out like a sneeze

kural.pope_couplet: In womanly reserve I deemed myself beyond assail;But love will come abroad, and casts away the veil
kural.pope_exp: I say I would be firm, but alas, my malady breaks out from its concealment and appears in public

kural.pope_couplet: The dignity that seeks not him who acts as foe,Is the one thing that loving heart can never know
kural.pope_exp: The dignity that would not go after an absent lover is not known to those who are sticken by love

kural.pope_couplet: My grief how full of grace, I pray you see!It seeks to follow him that hateth me
kural.pope_exp: The sorrow I have endured by desiring to go after my absent lover, in what way is it excellent?

kural.pope_couplet: No sense of shame my gladdened mind shall prove,When he returns my longing heart to bless with love
kural.pope_exp: I know nothing like shame when my beloved does from love (just) what is desired (by me)

kural.pope_couplet: The words of that deceiver, versed in every wily art,Are instruments that break through every guard of woman's heart
kural.pope_exp: Are not the enticing words of my trick-abounding roguish lover the weapon that breaks away my feminine firmness?

kural.pope_couplet: 'I 'll shun his greeting'; saying thus with pride away I went:I held him in my arms, for straight I felt my heart relent
kural.pope_exp: I said I would feign dislike and so went (away); (but) I embraced him the moment I say my mind began to unite with him!

kural.pope_couplet: 'We 'll stand aloof and then embrace': is this for them to say,Whose hearts are as the fat that in the blaze dissolves away
kural.pope_exp: Is it possible for those whose hearts melt like fat in the fire to say they can feign a strong dislike and remain so?

kural.pope_couplet: My eyes have lost their brightness, sight is dimmed; my fingers worn,With nothing on the wall the days since I was left forlorn
kural.pope_exp: My finger has worn away by marking (on the wall) the days he has been absent while my eyes have lost their lustre and begin to fail

kural.pope_couplet: O thou with gleaming jewels decked, could I forget for this one day,Henceforth these bracelets from my arms will slip, my beauty worn away
kural.pope_exp: O you bright-jewelled maid, if I forget (him) today, my shoulders will lose their beauty even in the other life and make my bracelets loose

kural.pope_couplet: On victory intent, His mind sole company he went;And I yet life sustain And long to see his face again
kural.pope_exp: I still live by longing for the arrival of him who has gone out of love for victory and with valour as his guide

kural.pope_couplet: 'He comes again, who left my side, and I shall taste love's joy,'-My heart with rapture swells, when thoughts like these my mind employ
kural.pope_exp: My heart is rid of its sorrow and swells with rapture to think of my absent lover returning with his love

kural.pope_couplet: O let me see my spouse again and sate these longing eyes!That instant from my wasted frame all pallor flies
kural.pope_exp: May I look on my lover till I am satisfied and thereafter will vanish the sallowness of my slender shoulders

kural.pope_couplet: O let my spouse but come again to me one day!I'll drink that nectar: wasting grief shall flee away
kural.pope_exp: May my husband return some day; and then will I enjoy (him) so as to destroy all this agonizing sorrow

kural.pope_couplet: Shall I draw back, or yield myself, or shall both mingled be,When he returns, my spouse, dear as these eyes to me
kural.pope_exp: On the return of him who is as dear as my eyes, am I displeased or am I to embrace (him); or am I to do both?

kural.pope_couplet: O would my king would fight, o'ercome, devide the spoil;At home, to-night, the banquet spread should crown the toil
kural.pope_exp: Let the king fight and gain (victories); (but) let me be united to my wife and feast the evening

kural.pope_couplet: One day will seem like seven to those who watch and yearnFor that glad day when wanderers from afar return
kural.pope_exp: To those who suffer waiting for the day of return of their distant lovers one day is as long as seven days

kural.pope_couplet: What's my return, the meeting hour, the wished-for greeting worth,If she heart-broken lie, with all her life poured forth
kural.pope_exp: After (my wife) has died of a broken heart, what good will there be if she is to receive me, has received me, or has even embraced me?

kural.pope_couplet: Thou hid'st it, yet thine eye, disdaining all restraint,Something, I know not, what, would utter of complaint
kural.pope_exp: Though you would conceal (your feelings), your painted eyes would not, for, transgressing (their bounds), they tell (me) something

kural.pope_couplet: The simple one whose beauty fills mine eye, whose shoulders curveLike bambu stem, hath all a woman's modest sweet reserve
kural.pope_exp: Unusually great is the female simplicity of your maid whose beauty fills my eyes and whose shoulders resemble the bamboo

kural.pope_couplet: As through the crystal beads is seen the thread on which they 're strungSo in her beauty gleams some thought cannot find a tongue
kural.pope_exp: There is something that is implied in the beauty of this woman, like the thread that is visible in a garland of gems

kural.pope_couplet: As fragrance in the opening bud, some secret liesConcealed in budding smile of this dear damsel's eyes
kural.pope_exp: There is something in the unmatured smile of this maid like the fragrance that is contained in an unblossomed bud

kural.pope_couplet: The secret wiles of her with thronging armlets decked,Are medicines by which my raising grief is checked
kural.pope_exp: The well-meant departure of her whose bangles are tight-fitting contains a remedy that can cure my great sorrow

kural.pope_couplet: While lovingly embracing me, his heart is only grieved:It makes me think that I again shall live of love bereaved
kural.pope_exp: The embrace that fills me with comfort and gladness is capable of enduring (my former) sorrow and meditating on his want of love

kural.pope_couplet: My severance from the lord of this cool shore,My very armlets told me long before
kural.pope_exp: My bracelets have understood before me the (mental) separation of him who rules the cool seashore

kural.pope_couplet: My loved one left me, was it yesterday?Days seven my pallid body wastes away
kural.pope_exp: It was but yesterday my lover departed (from me); and it is seven days since my complexion turned sallow

kural.pope_couplet: She viewed her tender arms, she viewed the armlets from them slid;She viewed her feet: all this the lady did
kural.pope_exp: She looked at her bracelets, her tender shoulders, and her feet; this was what she did there (significantly)

kural.pope_couplet: To show by eye the pain of love, and for relief to pray,Is womanhood's most womanly device, men say
kural.pope_exp: To express their love-sickness by their eyes and resort to begging bespeaks more than ordinary female excellence

kural.pope_couplet: Gladness at the thought, rejoicing at the sight,Not palm-tree wine, but love, yields such delight
kural.pope_exp: To please by thought and cheer by sight is peculiar, not to liquor but lust

kural.pope_couplet: When as palmyra tall, fulness of perfect love we gain,Distrust can find no place small as the millet grain
kural.pope_exp: If women have a lust that exceeds even the measure of the palmyra fruit, they will not desire (to feign) dislike even as much as the millet

kural.pope_couplet: Although his will his only law, he lightly value me,My heart knows no repose unless my lord I see
kural.pope_exp: Though my eyes disregard me and do what is pleasing to my husband, still will they not be satisfied unless they see him

kural.pope_couplet: My friend, I went prepared to show a cool disdain;My heart, forgetting all, could not its love restrain
kural.pope_exp: My heart, forgetting all, could not its love restrain

kural.pope_couplet: The eye sees not the rod that paints it; nor can ISee any fault, when I behold my husband nigh
kural.pope_exp: Like the eyes which see not the pencil that paints it, I cannot see my husband's fault (just) when I meet him

kural.pope_couplet: When him I see, to all his faults I 'm blind;But when I see him not, nothing but faults I find
kural.pope_exp: When I see my husband, I do not see any faults; but when I do not see him, I do not see anything but faults

kural.pope_couplet: As those of rescue sure, who plunge into the stream,So did I anger feign, though it must falsehood seem
kural.pope_exp: Like those who leap into a stream which they know will carry them off, why should a wife feign dislike which she knows cannot hold out long?

kural.pope_couplet: Though shameful ill it works, dear is the palm-tree wineTo drunkards; traitor, so to me that breast of thine
kural.pope_exp: O you rogue! your breast is to me what liquor is to those who rejoice in it, though it only gives them an unpleasant disgrace

kural.pope_couplet: Love is tender as an opening flower In season dueTo gain its perfect bliss is rapture known to few
kural.pope_exp: Sexual delight is more delicate than a flower, and few are those who understand its real nature

kural.pope_couplet: Her eye, as I drew nigh one day, with anger shone:By love o'erpowered, her tenderness surpassed my own
kural.pope_exp: She once feigned dislike in her eyes, but the warmth of her embrace exceeded my own

kural.pope_couplet: You see his heart is his aloneO heart, why not be all my own
kural.pope_exp: O my soul! although you have seen how his soul stands by him, how is it you do not stand by me?

kural.pope_couplet: 'Tis plain, my heart, that he 's estranged from thee;Why go to him as though he were not enemy
kural.pope_exp: O my soul! although you have known him who does not love me, still do you go to him, saying "he will not be displeased."

kural.pope_couplet: 'The ruined have no friends, 'they say; and so, my heart,To follow him, at thy desire, from me thou dost depart
kural.pope_exp: O my soul! do you follow him at pleasure under the belief that the ruined have no friends?

kural.pope_couplet: 'See, thou first show offended pride, and then submit,' I bade;Henceforth such council who will share with thee my heart
kural.pope_exp: O my soul! you would not first seem sulky and then enjoy (him); who then would in future consult you about such things?

kural.pope_couplet: I fear I shall not gain, I fear to lose him when I gain;And thus my heart endures unceasing pain
kural.pope_exp: My soul fears when it is without him; it also fears when it is with him; it is subject to incessant sorrow

kural.pope_couplet: My heart consumes me when I ponder lone,And all my lover's cruelty bemoan
kural.pope_exp: My mind has been (here) in order to eat me up (as it were) whenever I think of him in my solitude

kural.pope_couplet: Fall'n 'neath the sway of this ignoble foolish heart,Which will not him forget, I have forgotten shame
kural.pope_exp: I have even forgotten my modesty, having been caught in my foolish mind which is not dignified enough to forget him

kural.pope_couplet: If I contemn him, then disgrace awaits me evermore;My soul that seeks to live his virtues numbers o'er
kural.pope_exp: My soul which clings to life thinks only of his (own) gain in the belief that it would be disgraceful for it to despise him

kural.pope_couplet: And who will aid me in my hour of grief,If my own heart comes not to my relief
kural.pope_exp: Who would help me out of one's distress, when one's own soul refuses help to one?

kural.pope_couplet: A trifle is unfriendliness by aliens shown,When our own heart itself is not our own
kural.pope_exp: It is hardly possible for strangers to behave like relations, when one's own soul acts like a stranger

kural.pope_couplet: Be still reserved, decline his profferred love;A little while his sore distress we 'll prove
kural.pope_exp: Let us witness awhile his keen suffering; just feign dislike and embrace him not

kural.pope_couplet: A cool reserve is like the salt that seasons well the mess,Too long maintained, 'tis like the salt's excess
kural.pope_exp: A little dislike is like salt in proportion; to prolong it a little is like salt a little too much

kural.pope_couplet: 'Tis heaping griefs on those whose hearts are grieved;To leave the grieving one without a fond embrace
kural.pope_exp: For men not to embrace those who have feigned dislike is like torturing those already in agony

kural.pope_couplet: To use no kind conciliating art when lover grieves,Is cutting out the root of tender winding plant that droops
kural.pope_exp: Not to reconcile those who have feigned dislike is like cutting a faded creeper at its root

kural.pope_couplet: Even to men of good and worthy mind, the petulanceOf wives with flowery eyes lacks not a lovely grace
kural.pope_exp: An increased shyness in those whose eyes are like flowers is beautiful even to good and virtuous husbands

kural.pope_couplet: Love without hatred is ripened fruit;Without some lesser strife, fruit immature
kural.pope_exp: Sexual pleasure, without prolonged and short-lived dislike, is like too ripe, and unripe fruit

kural.pope_couplet: A lovers' quarrel brings its pain, when mind afraidAsks doubtful, 'Will reunion sweet be long delayed?'
kural.pope_exp: The doubt as to whether intercourse would take place soon or not, creates a sorrow (even) in feigned dislike

kural.pope_couplet: What good can grieving do, when none who loveAre there to know the grief thy soul endures
kural.pope_exp: What avails sorrow when I am without a wife who can understand the cause of my sorrow?

kural.pope_couplet: Water is pleasant in the cooling shade;So coolness for a time with those we love
kural.pope_exp: Like water in the shade, dislike is delicious only in those who love

kural.pope_couplet: Of her who leaves me thus in variance languishing,To think within my heart with love is fond desire
kural.pope_exp: It is nothing but strong desire that makes her mind unite with me who can leave her to her own dislike

kural.pope_couplet: From thy regard all womankind Enjoys an equal grace;O thou of wandering fickle mind, I shrink from thine embrace
kural.pope_exp: You are given to prostitution; all those who are born as womankind enjoy you with their eyes in an ordinary way I will not embrace you

kural.pope_couplet: One day we silent sulked; he sneezed: The reason well I knew;He thought that I, to speak well pleased, Would say, 'Long life to you!'
kural.pope_exp: When I continued to be sulky he sneezed and thought I would (then) wish him a long life

kural.pope_couplet: I wreathed with flowers one day my brow, The angry tempest lowers;She cries, 'Pray, for what woman now Do you put on your flowers?'
kural.pope_exp: Even if I were adorned with a garland of branch-flowers, she would say I did so to show it to another woman

kural.pope_couplet: 'I love you more than all beside,' 'T was thus I gently spoke;'What all, what all?' she instant cried; And all her anger woke
kural.pope_exp: When I said I loved her more than any other woman, she said "more than others, yes, more than others," and remained sulky

kural.pope_couplet: 'While here I live, I leave you not,' I said to calm her fearsShe cried, 'There, then, I read your thought'; And straight dissolved in tears
kural.pope_exp: When I said I would never part from her in this life her eyes were filled with tears

kural.pope_couplet: 'Each day I called to mind your charms,' 'O, then, you had forgot,'She cried, and then her opened arms, Forthwith embraced me not
kural.pope_exp: When I said I had remembered her, she said I had forgotten her and relaxing her embrace, began to feign dislike

kural.pope_couplet: She hailed me when I sneezed one day; But straight with anger seized,She cried; 'Who was the woman, pray, Thinking of whom you sneezed?'
kural.pope_exp: When I sneezed she blessed me, but at once changed (her mind) and wept, asking, "At the thought of whom did you sneeze?"

kural.pope_couplet: And so next time I checked my sneeze; She forthwith wept and cried,(That woman difficult to please), 'Your thoughts from me you hide'
kural.pope_exp: When I suppressed my sneezing, she wept saying, "I suppose you (did so) to hide from me your own people's remembrance of you"

kural.pope_couplet: I then began to soothe and coax, To calm her jealous mind;'I see', quoth she, 'to other folks How you are wondrous kind
kural.pope_exp: 'I see', quoth she, 'to other folks How you are wondrous kind' Even when I try to remove her dislike, she is displeased and says, "This is the way you behave

kural.pope_couplet: I silent sat, but thought the more, And gazed on her Then sheCried out, 'While thus you eye me o'er, Tell me whose form you see'
kural.pope_exp: Even when I look on her contemplating (her beauty), she is displeased and says, "With whose thought have you (thus) looked on my person?"

kural.pope_couplet: Although there be no fault in him, the sweetness of his loveHath power in me a fretful jealousy to move
kural.pope_exp: Although my husband is free from defects, the way in which he embraces me is such as to make me feign dislike

kural.pope_couplet: My 'anger feigned' gives but a little pain;And when affection droops, it makes it bloom again
kural.pope_exp: His love will increase though it may (at first seem to) fade through the short-lived distress caused by (my) dislike

kural.pope_couplet: Is there a bliss in any world more utterly divine,Than 'coyness' gives, when hearts as earth and water join
kural.pope_exp: Is there a celestial land that can please like the feigned dislike of those whose union resembles that of earth and water?

kural.pope_couplet: 'Within the anger feigned' that close love's tie doth bind,A weapon lurks, which quite breaks down my mind
kural.pope_exp: In prolonged dislike after an embrace there is a weapon that can break my heart

kural.pope_couplet: Though free from fault, from loved one's tender armsTo be estranged a while hath its own special charms
kural.pope_exp: Though free from defects, men feel pleased when they cannot embrace the delicate shoulders of those whom they love

kural.pope_couplet: 'Tis sweeter to digest your food than 'tis to eat;In love, than union's self is anger feigned more sweet
kural.pope_exp: To digest what has been eaten is more delightful than to eat more; likewise love is more delightful in dislike than intercourse

kural.pope_couplet: In lovers' quarrels, 'tis the one that first gives way,That in re-union's joy is seen to win the day
kural.pope_exp: Those are conquerors whose dislike has been defeated and that is proved by the love (which

kural.pope_couplet: And shall we ever more the sweetness know of that embraceWith dewy brow; to which 'feigned anger' lent its piquant grace
kural.pope_exp: Will I enjoy once more through her dislike, the pleasure of that love that makes her forehead perspire?

kural.pope_couplet: Let her, whose jewels brightly shine, aversion feignThat I may still plead on, O night, prolong thy reign
kural.pope_exp: May the bright-jewelled one feign dislike, and may the night be prolonged for me to implore her!

kural.pope_couplet: A 'feigned aversion' coy to pleasure gives a zest;The pleasure's crowned when breast is clasped to breast
kural.pope_exp: Dislike adds delight to love; and a hearty embrace (thereafter) will add delight to dislike
